Okay. This is… the big one. The question everyone wants to ask, and the hardest one to answer. It's not a simple story, and it's definitely not a decision I took lightly.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was *best* for the baby. And honestly, what was best for the baby wasn't me.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am, what I want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I don't have the financial stability, the emotional maturity, or the life experience to give a child everything they need.

I thought about all the things a baby deserves: a stable home, a loving family, a good education, opportunities to pursue their dreams. And I realized that I couldn't provide those things, not right now.

I talked to Bren, my stepmom, a lot. She helped me think through all the options. We talked about abortion, about raising the baby myself, about adoption. And adoption just felt… right.

It felt like the most selfless thing I could do. It felt like giving the baby the best possible chance at a happy life.

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby, they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited. They're kind and loving and they're going to be wonderful parents.

It's not easy. It's heartbreaking, actually. Knowing that I'm not going to be the one raising my child. But I know that I'm making the right decision.

It's not about giving up on my baby. It's about giving my baby a future. And that's something I can live with. It's something I have to live with.

It's a complicated decision, and it's one that I'll probably be grappling with for the rest of my life. But I'm at peace with it. I'm doing what I think is best for everyone involved. And that's all I can do.

It's not a happy ending, but it's a hopeful one. And that's enough. For now.

So yeah. I'm not feeling good about it. At all. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do. And I don't know how it's going to go. I just… I just hope they can forgive me. And I hope they can still love me. Even after this. That's all I want.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not like they're *bad* parents, you know? It's just… complicated.

With my dad, Mac, it's mostly because he's… not great with feelings. He's a good guy, and he loves me, but he's not the type to sit down and have a heart-to-heart. He's more of a "fix the problem" kind of guy. And this isn't a problem you can fix with a wrench or a hammer.

I didn't want to burden him with it. I didn't want to see him upset. He's already been through so much, with my mom leaving and everything. I didn't want to add to his stress.

And with Bren… it's different. She's amazing. She's supportive and understanding and she always knows what to say. But I was still scared to tell her. I was afraid of disappointing her. I was afraid of ruining our relationship.

It's also just… hard to be vulnerable. To admit that you're struggling. To ask for help. I've always been pretty independent, and I'm used to handling things on my own.

Okay, this is the big one, right? The question everyone's been dancing around. It's not an easy answer, and it's not something I came to lightly.

It wouldn't be fair to the baby. It wouldn't be fair to me.

I want that baby to have everything – a stable home, loving parents, opportunities to learn and grow. I want that baby to be wanted and cherished. And right now, I can't provide that.

I've met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are going to adopt the baby, and they are amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they are so excited and prepared. They're kind and compassionate and they have so much love to give.

Knowing that my baby will be going to a home like that… it makes it a little bit easier. It doesn't make it painless, but it makes it feel like the right decision.

It's not about me not wanting the baby. It's about wanting what's best for the baby. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is to let go.

It's a selfless act, I guess. And it's the hardest thing I've ever had to do. But I know that it's the right thing.

I want the baby to have a good life. And I believe that adoption is the best way to give it that. It's not the easy way, but it's the right way. And that's all that matters.

It's not a perfect solution, and it's not something I'm going to get over quickly. But I'm trying to focus on the positive. I'm trying to believe that this is the best possible outcome for everyone involved. And I'm trying to be brave. Because it takes a lot of courage to make a decision like this. And I'm doing it. For the baby.

Okay, this is… the hardest part. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes. This is about my baby's future. So, I've thought about this *a lot*.

First and foremost, they need to be **kind**. Genuinely kind. Not just putting on a show for me, but truly caring people. I want my baby to be loved and cherished, and to feel safe and secure.

They need to be **stable**. I want them to have a stable home and a stable life. I want them to be financially secure, and emotionally mature. I want them to be able to provide a good upbringing for my baby.

They need to be **open-minded**. I want them to be accepting of all kinds of people, and to be willing to embrace diversity. I want them to teach my baby to be tolerant and compassionate.

They need to be **patient**. Raising a child is hard work. It requires a lot of patience and understanding. I want them to be able to handle the challenges that come with parenthood.

And they need to be **honest**. I want them to be honest with me, and with my baby. I want them to be able to communicate openly and honestly about their feelings and their expectations.

It's not about finding perfect parents. No one is perfect. It's about finding parents who are willing to love and care for my baby, and to give them the best possible life.

Mark and Vanessa… they seem to have all of those qualities. They're kind, they're stable, they're open-minded, they're patient, and they're honest. And I feel good about them. I feel like they'll be good parents.

It's still scary, though. It's still hard to let go. But I know that it's the right thing to do. And I want my baby to have a life that I can't give them. A life filled with love, and happiness, and opportunity. And I think Mark and Vanessa can give them that.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… the hard part.)

Okay. This isn't going to be easy. I already know that. It's going to be the hardest thing I've ever done.

I'm going to lean on Bren. She's been my rock through all of this, and I know she'll be there for me when the time comes. I'm going to talk to her about my feelings, and I'm going to let her comfort me.

It's going to be a long and difficult journey. But I'm determined to get through it. I'm determined to heal. And I'm determined to move on with my life.

I know it's going to hurt. But I also know that I'm strong enough to handle it. And I know that I'm not alone.

It's not about forgetting the baby. It's about learning to live with the loss. And about finding a way to move forward with hope and optimism.

It's going to be okay. Eventually. I have to believe that. And I have to keep telling myself that. Even when it doesn't feel true.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? People still ask me about that? It's been, like, forever.

Okay, look. It's just… weird, okay? Like, I'm not a pizza. I'm not a package. I'm a person carrying a person. And the word "deliver" makes it sound like I'm just dropping something off at a doorstep.

It's just a weird word to use in this context. "Give" is much better. Or "place." Or even just "have a baby." Anything but "deliver."

Bren tried to explain it to me, said it's just a common term and people don't mean anything by it. But I still think it's weird. And I still cringe every time I hear it.

It's just… a thing. A Juno thing. Don't ask me to explain it further. It's just weird, okay? And I'm sticking with it.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That was… a whole thing.

Okay, so, originally, I was just going to go with Bren. She's the sensible one, the one who keeps me grounded. But my dad, Mac… he got all weird about it.

It was weird having him there, but it was also… nice. It reminded me that he loved me, even if he didn't always know how to show it.

So yeah. I let him come because I was scared, and he was scared, and we needed each other. It wasn't ideal, but it was okay. It was… family. And sometimes, family is just a little bit messy and awkward. But it's still family.

(Sighs) Okay, you're getting deep again. And honestly? It's a question I ask myself a lot.

It's… unsettling, not knowing. Everyone else seems to have it figured out. They know what they want, who they are, what they're good at. And I just… don't.

I'm not the popular girl. I'm not the smart girl. I'm not the athletic girl. I'm just… Juno. And sometimes, that feels like it's not enough.

I try to define myself by my interests – music, vintage clothes, movies. But those are just things I *like*. They don't define who I *am*.

And then there's the whole pregnancy thing. That's definitely thrown a wrench into my self-discovery process. It's like, who am I now? Am I just a mom? Or am I still Juno, the sarcastic, independent teenager?

I think… I think it's okay not to know. Maybe we're not supposed to have all the answers. Maybe life is about figuring things out as you go along.

Bren says that I'm still growing and changing, and that it's okay to not have a fixed identity. She says that I'm allowed to explore different parts of myself, and to try new things.

And I think she's right. I don't need to label myself. I don't need to fit into a box. I can just be… me. Whatever that means.

It's scary, not knowing. But it's also kind of exciting. It means that I have the freedom to become whoever I want to be. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

So yeah. I don't know what kind of girl I am. And honestly? I'm starting to be okay with that. Maybe the point isn't to *find* yourself, but to *create* yourself. And that's something I'm willing to try. Even if it's messy and complicated. Because life is messy and complicated. And that's okay.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that* moment. Ugh. It feels like a lifetime ago, but also like yesterday.

Relieved because the tension between my dad and Leah was so thick you could cut it with a knife. He was being all passive-aggressive and making little comments about her clothes and her music and everything. It was awful. And I just wanted it to stop.

Upstairs, Leah and I just sat in silence for a while. We were both really upset. And then she started crying. And I just held her.

It was a turning point, I think. It was the moment I realized that things were never going to be the same between Leah and me. And it was the moment I realized that my dad wasn't always going to understand me.

Bren saved us, though. She always does. She just knew when to step in and diffuse the situation. She's the best.

So yeah. Relieved, angry, and sad. That's how I reacted. It was a really complicated moment. And it's a moment I'll never forget. It was the beginning of the end of a really important friendship. And it was a reminder that life is messy and unpredictable. And that sometimes, all you can do is just hold on tight and try to survive.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. And it's something Bren and I have talked about endlessly.

At first, I wasn't sure. It felt… weird. Like, trying to have a relationship with a baby I gave up. It felt like it would just make things harder.

But then Mark and Vanessa explained their vision for an open adoption. They said they wanted me to be a part of the baby's life, to receive updates and photos, to know how he or she is doing. They said they wanted the baby to know about me, and about the reasons why I made the decision to give him or her up.

And the more I thought about it, the more I realized that it could be a good thing. Not for me, necessarily, but for the baby.

I want the baby to know that I loved him or her. I want the baby to know that I made this decision because I wanted him or her to have a good life. I want the baby to know that I'm not just some random person who gave him or her away.

And I think it would be good for me, too. It would give me some peace of mind, knowing that the baby is happy and healthy. It would help me to process my grief and to move on with my life.

It's still scary, though. It's scary to think about seeing the baby grow up with another family. It's scary to think about the possibility of getting attached and then having to step back.

But I think it's worth the risk. I think it's important to maintain some kind of connection, to show the baby that I care.

So yeah. I'm cautiously optimistic about the idea of an open adoption. It's not going to be easy, but I think it could be a good thing. For everyone involved. And I'm willing to try. Because I want what's best for the baby. Always.

(A long sigh. This is… not a fun memory.)

Ugh. That moment. That was… a punch to the gut. Seriously.

I mean, I *knew* adoption meant giving up the baby. I wasn't stupid. But I hadn't really thought about the legal stuff. I hadn't really thought about losing all my rights as a parent.

Gerta just… dropped it on me so casually. Like it was no big deal. "Oh, and just so you know, in an open adoption, you'll be signing away your legal rights."

And it just hit me. Like, *really* hit me. It wasn't just about giving the baby a good home. It was about giving up my claim to him or her forever.

I felt… numb. And scared. And incredibly sad.

It was like a part of me was being ripped away. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it any easier.

I remember looking at Gerta, and just… being angry. Not at her, exactly. But at the whole situation. At the fact that I was in this position in the first place.

I asked her if I could still see the baby. If I could still be a part of his or her life. And she said yes, but it wasn't the same. It wasn't the same as being a parent.

It was a really hard moment. It was a moment that made me realize just how much I was giving up. And it was a moment that made me question whether I was doing the right thing.

But ultimately, I knew I was. I knew that giving the baby a loving home was more important than my own feelings. But it still hurt. It still hurts. And I don't think it will ever stop hurting.

It was a really sobering moment. A really, really sobering moment. And it made me realize that adoption is not a simple process. It's complicated and emotional and heartbreaking. And it requires a lot of courage and selflessness. And I was trying to be courageous and selfless. But it didn't make it any easier.

Okay, that's… a complicated question. It's not something I think about all the time, because it's kinda painful, but it's definitely there.

Honestly? It's bittersweet.

It's amazing that she and Mark want a baby so much. It makes me feel good knowing that the baby will be loved and wanted. And it makes me feel like I'm doing the right thing, giving them the chance to be parents.

But it also… stings a little. Because it reminds me of everything I'm giving up. It reminds me of the life I won't have with this baby.

I see how excited she gets talking about nursery decorations and baby clothes, and it makes me happy for her, but also… sad for me. It's like watching someone else live the life I could have had.

But I try not to dwell on it. I try to focus on the fact that she's going to be a great mom. She's kind and patient and loving. And she and Mark are going to give this baby a wonderful life.

I think it's important for me to remember that this isn't about me. It's about what's best for the baby. And what's best for the baby is to be raised by parents who are ready and able to provide for him or her.

So yeah. It's bittersweet. I'm happy for Vanessa, but I'm also sad for myself. It's a complicated mix of emotions. And I'm still trying to process it all. But I know that I'm doing the right thing. And that's what matters.

It's just… hard. It's really hard.

(Sighs, rolling eyes slightly) Okay, you want my honest opinion about Mark? Fine.

And that's what I liked about it. It showed me that he was real. That he wasn't trying to be someone he wasn't.

He also talked about how excited he was to be a dad. About how he and Vanessa had been trying for a long time, and how they were so grateful for the opportunity.

He didn't make it about *me*. He didn't make it about his own feelings. He made it about the baby. And that's what mattered.

He seemed genuinely excited to provide a loving and stable home for the baby. And he seemed genuinely committed to being a good father.

Vanessa's great too, don't get me wrong. But Mark's vulnerability… it was just… reassuring. It made me feel like I was making the right decision.

He's not perfect, obviously. No one is. But he's a good guy. And I think he and Vanessa are going to be amazing parents.

So yeah. I think Mark's response was perfect. It was honest, it was heartfelt, and it was exactly what I needed to hear. It made me feel a little bit better about everything. And that's saying something.

(Scoffs) Oh, *that*. You want to know about the Loring's house? Seriously? Okay, fine. But don't judge. It's… weird.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… hard to talk about, even now.)

It's… complicated. It's not simple happiness, or simple sadness. It's a whole mess of feelings all tangled up together.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, okay, we're *still* talking about that? Seriously? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment.

So yeah. That's why I mocked his use of "ASAP." It was a moment of weakness. A moment of sarcasm. And a moment of frustration. And I regret it. A little bit. But not entirely. It was kind of funny, too. Don't tell him I said that.

Okay, finally a question I can really sink my teeth into. This is important. Don't underestimate the importance of a good guitar.

My preferred brand is **Fender.** Specifically, a Fender Telecaster.

Yeah, I know, it's kinda cliché. But it's a classic for a reason.

I also love the simplicity of it. It's not a flashy guitar. It's just a solid, reliable instrument that gets the job done.

I tried playing a Gibson Les Paul once, but it just didn't feel right. It was too heavy and too complicated. I prefer the feel of a Telecaster in my hands. It's like an extension of my body.

Plus, a lot of my favorite guitarists play Fender Telecasters. Like, Keith Richards, Bruce Springsteen, and… well, okay, maybe not Joan Jett, but still.

So yeah. Fender Telecaster. It's the perfect guitar for me. It's simple, reliable, and it sounds amazing. And it's a guitar that I can grow with. It's a guitar that will last a lifetime. And honestly, it just *feels* right. It's the guitar for a sarcastic, independent, music-loving teenager. It just is.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about that? It was a moment of weakness, okay? A lapse in judgment. A desperate attempt to impress Paulie Bleeker.

Ugh, okay. Talking about Mark is… complicated. But alright, I'll try.

It wasn't like… romantic or anything. Not at all. It was just… comfortable. And surprisingly easy.

It was… a safe space. A place where I could just be myself, and not worry about what anyone else thought.

It was also… a way to connect with the baby. Like, I was sharing something beautiful with him or her, even before he or she was born.

It wasn't a romantic connection. It was something else. Something… deeper. It was a connection of souls, I guess. Or something like that. I'm not good at explaining feelings.

It just felt… good. And I'm going to miss it. A lot. It was one of the few bright spots in a really difficult time. And I'm grateful for that. Seriously.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Roosevelt.

It's a long story, but I'll give you the short version.

I was at a thrift store with my dad, looking for a guitar. I'd been saving up for months, and I was finally ready to buy one.

And I found this old, beat-up acoustic guitar. It wasn't much to look at, but it felt… right. It just felt like it belonged in my hands.

My dad asked me what I was going to name it. And I just blurted out "Roosevelt."

He looked at me like I was crazy. "Roosevelt? Why Roosevelt?"

And I didn't even know. It just popped into my head. I think it was because I'd been reading about Theodore Roosevelt in history class. He was a pretty cool guy. Adventurous, independent, a little bit quirky.

And the guitar just… felt like a Roosevelt. It was a little bit rough around the edges, but it had a lot of character.

So I named it Roosevelt. And it's stuck ever since.

It's kinda silly, I know. But I love that guitar. It's my escape. It's my creative outlet. And it's a reminder that sometimes, the best things in life are the ones you least expect.

Plus, it's fun to say. "I'm gonna go play Roosevelt." It just sounds cool. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay. That's… complicated. It's not like sending a text saying "Just finished my homework!" It's a whole *thing*.

At first, it was really awkward. I mean, I barely knew them. And suddenly I'm having to tell them about doctor's appointments and morning sickness and all the other gross details of being pregnant. It felt weird, you know? Like I was just a walking incubator.

It's still a little strange, though. It's hard to get used to the idea that these people are going to be the baby's parents. But they seem really excited, and they seem really prepared. And that makes me feel a little bit better.

I think it's important to keep them updated, so they can be involved in the process. It's their baby, too. And I want them to feel like they're a part of it.

But it's also hard. It's a constant reminder that I'm not going to be raising this baby. And that's… painful.

So yeah. It's a mixed bag. It's awkward, and it's emotional, and it's a little bit scary. But it's also necessary. And I'm grateful that Vanessa and Mark are being so understanding and supportive. It makes the whole thing a little bit easier. A little bit less lonely.

(Sighs, looks away for a moment, then back with a determined look)

Okay. You want the real reason? It's not just about me not being ready. It's not just about school or my future. It's… it's about wanting this baby to have the *best* life possible.

And I know, deep down, that I can't give that to it. Not right now. Not ever, really.

So, how did I feel? It was complicated. It was scary. It was heartbreaking. But it was also… beautiful. It was a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there is always hope. And it was a lesson in love, and sacrifice, and the importance of doing what's best for everyone involved.

It's still… a lot to process. But I'm getting there. And I'm grateful for the experience, even though it was difficult. It made me who I am today. And I wouldn't trade that for anything.

Ugh. Bleeker. Just saying his name makes me cringe a little. It was… not a good scene. Not at all.

Okay, so, I'd been avoiding him for a few days. I knew I had to tell him, but I was terrified. He was… Bleeker. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And I knew he wasn't exactly prepared for this kind of news.

I finally cornered him in the music room after school. He was practicing his guitar, and I just… blurted it out.

"I'm pregnant."

He stopped playing. He just stared at me, his mouth hanging open. It was like I'd spoken a different language.

Then he started to laugh.

Not a mean laugh, but a nervous, disbelieving laugh. He thought I was joking.

"You're… you're kidding, right?" he said.

And I just shook my head. "No. I'm serious."

His face went white. He started to stammer, trying to find the right words. He kept saying "Oh my god" over and over again.

He wasn't angry, or upset, or anything like that. He was just… completely overwhelmed. He didn't know what to do.

He kept asking me if I was sure, and if I wanted to keep the baby, and if I needed help. But he didn't really *listen* to my answers. He was too caught up in his own panic.

It was… disappointing. I had hoped for a more supportive reaction. I had hoped he would be there for me. But he just wasn't.

He ended up saying he needed time to think. Which, okay, fair enough. But he didn't really follow up. He just kind of disappeared.

It was a really awkward and painful conversation. And it was the beginning of the end of our… whatever it was.

Honestly, it was a relief when it was over. It was just… a mess. And I knew, deep down, that he wasn't the right person to help me through this.

So yeah. That's how I told Bleeker. It wasn't pretty. And it definitely wasn't what I expected. But it was a necessary step. And it ultimately led me to make the best decision for myself and for the baby. Even if it meant letting go of someone I once cared about.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

But then I would remember Mark and Vanessa. And I would remember how excited they were to become parents. And I would remember that they could give the baby a life that I couldn’t. A stable home, a loving family, opportunities that I just couldn’t provide.

It was also really important to me that I had a say in who adopted the baby. I wanted to choose a family that I trusted, a family that would love and care for my child. And Mark and Vanessa were perfect. They were kind and compassionate and they just… felt right.

Even after the adoption was finalized, it was still hard. I missed the baby. I wondered what he or she was doing. I wondered if he or she was happy.

But I also knew that I had made the right decision. It wasn’t the easy decision, but it was the right one.

It’s still something I think about every day. But it’s not as painful as it used to be. I’ve learned to accept that my life took an unexpected turn. And I’ve learned to find strength in my decision.

It doesn’t mean I don’t feel a sense of loss. But it also means I feel a sense of hope. Hope for the baby’s future. And hope for my own.

It was… a really hard thing to go through. But it made me who I am today. And I’m grateful for the lessons I learned. Even the painful ones.

(Rolls eyes playfully) Seriously? We *just* had this conversation. Are you not paying attention?

I listen to vinyl whenever I can. There's just something about the sound of a record that's different from digital music. It's warmer and more organic.

So yeah. That's pretty much my musical taste in a nutshell. It's a little bit eclectic, a little bit weird, and a lot of fun. And it's the music that makes me feel alive. Don't judge. It's good stuff. Seriously.

(Eyes widen, a slow grin spreads across her face)

Oh. *Oh*. You've done your research. Okay, you're officially cool.

"The Wizard of Gore"? Are you kidding me? It's… it's a masterpiece of bad taste. It's gloriously, hilariously, wonderfully awful.

It's not a *good* movie, obviously. The acting is terrible, the special effects are laughable, and the plot makes absolutely no sense. But that's what makes it so great!

It's so over-the-top and ridiculous that it's impossible not to enjoy it. It's the kind of movie you watch with a group of friends and just scream with laughter.

And the gore… oh, the gore. It's so fake and cheesy that it's actually kind of charming. It's like a cartoon version of violence.

I first saw it with Leah, and we were quoting it for weeks afterward. "It's a wizard! He conjures things!" It's become one of our inside jokes.

It's the perfect movie to watch when you're feeling down or stressed. It's a guaranteed mood booster.

So yeah. "The Wizard of Gore." It's a cinematic treasure. A beautiful disaster. A glorious mess. And if you haven't seen it, you're missing out. Seriously. Go watch it right now. You won't regret it. Unless you're easily offended. Then maybe skip it. But you'd be missing out.

Ugh. Madison. Okay, look, no offense to anyone named Madison, but… it's a bit… basic.

It was *super* popular when I was little. Like, every other girl in my class was named Madison. It just feels… overdone. Like a default setting.

It's not a *bad* name, necessarily. It's just… uninspired. It doesn't have any personality. It doesn't make me think of anything specific.

I prefer names that are a little bit more unique, a little bit more quirky. Like, I like names that have a story behind them. Or names that sound cool.

I'm not saying you shouldn't name your daughter Madison. If you like it, then go for it. But just… be prepared for her to have to say "Madison with an 'i' " for the rest of her life.

Honestly, I'd rather name a kid something like Beatrix or Clementine. Or even Juniper. Those names have character.

So yeah. Madison. It's… fine. But it's not my favorite. It's just a little bit too… mainstream for my taste. I like things a little bit weirder. It's just me. Don't judge.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. So, people act like it's this simple, clean decision. Like I just woke up one day and said, "Yeah, I'll just give my baby away." It's not like that. It's messy. It's complicated. It's heartbreaking.

It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do, and I'm still processing it.

But I also know it's the right thing.

I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone raising a whole other human being. It wouldn't be fair to the baby. It wouldn't be fair to me.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been wanting a baby for so long, and they're going to give this child a life that I just can't provide right now. A stable home, a loving family, opportunities I could only dream of.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It doesn't erase the fact that I'm giving up a part of myself. There are days when I just… cry. I miss the baby already, and I haven't even met him or her yet.

But I know that I'm doing this out of love. I'm doing this because I want what's best for the baby. And that's what matters.

It's not about me. It's about giving this child the best possible start in life.

It's not a perfect solution. It's not a happy ending. But it's the right thing to do. And I'm trying to find peace with that.

It's still scary. It's still sad. But I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to believe that everything will be okay. For me, and for the baby.

So yeah. That's what I think about it. It's not easy. But it's the right thing to do. And I'm trying to be okay with that. Even if it takes a while.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a lot. It's like being a regular teenager on fast forward, with a whole lot of extra baggage.

Honestly? Most of the time, I don't handle it well. There are days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. Days when I feel completely overwhelmed and exhausted. Days when I just want everything to go away.

But I'm learning. I'm learning to take things one day at a time. I'm learning to prioritize. I'm learning to ask for help.

School is… hard. It's hard to focus when you're constantly worried about the baby, or about the adoption, or about what people are going to think. But I'm trying to stay on track. I know that getting a good education is important, and I don't want to ruin my future.

My friends… that's been the hardest part. Leah and I aren't really talking right now, and it breaks my heart. But I'm trying to focus on the friends who *are* still there for me.

And then there's the pregnancy itself. The morning sickness, the fatigue, the emotional rollercoaster… it's all exhausting. But I'm taking care of myself as best I can. I'm eating healthy, getting enough sleep (when I can), and going to all my doctor's appointments.

Bren has been a lifesaver. She's always there to listen, to offer advice, to just hold my hand when I need it. She's the one who keeps me grounded.

I also try to find moments of joy. Listening to music, watching movies, spending time with my dad. Those little things help me to recharge and to remember that life is still worth living.

It's not easy. It's the hardest thing I've ever done. But I'm doing it. And I'm learning a lot about myself along the way. I'm learning that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I'm learning that I can handle anything. And I'm learning that even in the midst of chaos, there's always hope.

So yeah. It's a mess. But I'm navigating it. And I'm trying to stay true to myself, even when it's difficult. And that's all I can do.

Ugh. That's… a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the central conflict of my entire existence right now.

I *hate* asking for help. It makes me feel weak and vulnerable. I want to be able to handle everything on my own. I want to be self-sufficient. I want to prove to myself and to everyone else that I'm strong and capable.

But the thing is, you can't do everything on your own. And pretending that you can is just exhausting.

I've learned that it's okay to lean on people. It's okay to ask for help when you need it. It doesn't make you any less of a person.

Bren has been really good about teaching me that. She always tells me that it's okay to be vulnerable, and that it's okay to ask for help. She says that true strength comes from knowing your limits and being willing to admit when you need assistance.

It's still a struggle, though. I still feel like I have to prove myself. I still feel like I have to be in control.

But I'm learning to let go. I'm learning to trust others. I'm learning to accept help when it's offered.

I think the key is to find a balance. To maintain your independence, but to also be open to support. To know when to stand on your own two feet, and when to ask for a helping hand.

It's not easy. It's a constant negotiation. But it's something I'm working on. And I think, with time, I'll get better at it.

Because ultimately, I realize that I'm not an island. I need people. And they need me. And that's okay. It's actually… good. It's what makes life worth living. It's what makes us human. So yeah. Balance. It's a work in progress. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, he was… a lot. A sweet lot, but a lot. And our relationship? It was a rollercoaster, honestly. A really awkward, teenage rollercoaster.

At first, it was just… weird. We were both trying to pretend everything was normal, like we could just keep hanging out and making mix tapes and ignoring the giant elephant in the room. Which, you know, didn't work.

He tried to be supportive, I guess. He brought me ginger ale when I was sick, and he offered to go to doctor's appointments with me. But he was also really awkward about it. He didn't know what to say, or how to act. And honestly, neither did I.

Then, he started getting all serious and talking about "us" and "the future." And that's when I started to freak out. Because I knew I wasn't going to keep the baby. And I knew he wasn't ready to be a dad.

It was a really hard conversation. I had to tell him that I was giving the baby up for adoption, and that I didn't see a future for us. It was awful. He was really hurt.

But he eventually came around. He realized that I was doing what was best for everyone involved. And he started to be a real friend. He stopped trying to fix things, and he just started listening.

He even helped me pick out a gift for the baby. It was a little stuffed animal. A polar bear. It was really sweet.

By the end, we weren't a couple anymore. But we were still friends. And I think we both grew up a lot throughout the whole process.

He taught me that it's okay to ask for help. And I taught him that it's okay to be vulnerable.

So yeah. Our relationship changed a lot. It started out awkward and uncertain, and it ended up being… something else. Something more mature. Something more real. It wasn't the love story I expected, but it was a story nonetheless. And I'll always be grateful for his friendship. Even if he is a little bit of a dork.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that* question. Seriously? It comes up more than you'd think.

Okay, look. It wasn't a deep, philosophical decision, alright? It wasn't like I was trying to make some grand statement about mythology or female empowerment.

My dad… he has a thing for Roman mythology. He's always reading books about it, watching documentaries about it. He's a history teacher, so it kinda comes with the territory.

When I was born, he and my mom were going through a really… intense phase with Roman gods and goddesses. They were arguing about who was the coolest, who was the most powerful, who had the best story.

And apparently, they settled on Juno. My dad thought she was strong and independent and a little bit rebellious. Which, looking back, is kinda ironic.

My mom liked the name, too. She said it sounded "regal" and "sophisticated." Which is… not exactly how I'd describe myself.

So they named me Juno. And that was that.

I didn't really think much about it growing up. It's just my name. But now, looking back, it's kinda funny. I'm not exactly a queen of the gods. I'm just a sarcastic teenager who got herself into a bit of a mess.

But hey, maybe there's a little bit of Juno in me after all. A little bit of strength, a little bit of independence, and a little bit of rebellion. And maybe that's not such a bad thing.

So yeah. That's the story of how I got my name. It's not as exciting as you might think. But it's the truth. And honestly, I'm kinda over talking about it. Can we move on now? Please?

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot.

Honestly? It was a punch to the gut. A really unexpected, really weird punch to the gut.

I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark were excited about the baby. But I didn't realize how much they were struggling with… connecting to it. With feeling like it was *real*.

I thought the ultrasound photo would be a happy moment. A way for them to see the baby and feel closer to it. But instead, it just… relieved Vanessa's anxiety. She said she was worried it wouldn't look like a real baby.

And it made me feel… disposable. Like I was just a vessel. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like the baby wasn't *my* baby, even for a little while.

I know it wasn't her intention to make me feel that way. She was just being honest. And I appreciate her honesty, I guess. But it still stung.

It made me realize how complicated this whole adoption process is. It's not just about giving a baby to a loving family. It's about navigating a lot of emotions, and a lot of expectations.

I talked to Bren about it. She said that Vanessa was probably just processing her own feelings, and that it didn't mean she didn't care about me.

But it still bothered me. It made me question my decision. It made me wonder if I was doing the right thing.

But ultimately, I realized that I had to focus on what was best for the baby. And if Vanessa needed that photo to feel connected to the baby, then that's what she needed.

It was a hard lesson to learn. But it was a lesson I needed to learn. And it made me even more determined to make this adoption a success. Even if it meant swallowing my pride and accepting that sometimes, things aren't going to be easy.

(Groans dramatically) Oh. *That*. Don't even get me started. Seriously. That was… a moment.

Okay, so, for anyone who doesn't know, Vanessa's mom, Eileen, is… intense. Like, a level ten on the "protective parent" scale. She's very particular about everything, and she has very strong opinions.

So when she found out I'd been at their house, unsupervised, while Vanessa was at work… let's just say she wasn't thrilled.

She cornered me in the kitchen and just… unleashed. It was a torrent of questions and accusations and warnings. She was asking me about my parents, my education, my intentions. She was basically interrogating me.

I tried to be polite, but it was hard. She was so intimidating. And she kept calling me "young lady," which just made me want to roll my eyes.

I think the worst part was when she started talking about the baby. She was saying things like, "Are you sure you're ready for this?" and "Have you thought about the long-term consequences?" and "What kind of life can you give this child?"

It was just… brutal.

I wanted to just run away and hide. But I knew I had to stand my ground. I had to show her that I was responsible and that I was making the right decision.

So I took a deep breath and I told her, as calmly as I could, that I had thought about everything. That I knew this wasn't going to be easy. But that I was committed to doing what was best for the baby.

And then, surprisingly, she softened a little. She said she was just worried about Vanessa and about the baby. And she said she wanted to make sure that I was making a responsible decision.

It wasn't a full apology, but it was a start. And it was enough to get me out of the kitchen alive.

Honestly, it was terrifying. But it also made me realize how much Vanessa and Mark meant to me. They were willing to open their hearts and their home to me, even with all the complications. And I was grateful for that.

And I learned a valuable lesson: never underestimate the power of a mom on a mission. Especially when that mom is Eileen. She's a force of nature. A very scary force of nature.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

It wasn't an easy decision. Not even a little bit. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. And I still think about it, you know? A lot.

But I knew, deep down, that I wasn't ready to be a mom. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to do with my life.

I didn't want to bring a baby into the world and not be able to give it everything it needed. I didn't want to hold it back. I wanted it to have a good life, a stable life, a life filled with love and opportunity.

And I knew I couldn't provide that. Not right now.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. She was really supportive. She didn't try to tell me what to do. She just listened, and she helped me think through all the options.

We met with a social worker, and we talked about adoption. And it just… felt right. It felt like the best option for everyone involved.

Mark and Vanessa… they seemed like amazing people. They were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. And they promised to love the baby unconditionally.

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about giving it a *chance*. A chance at a good life. A chance at a happy future.

It was a selfless decision, I guess. But it was also a selfish one. Because it allowed me to focus on my own future, to pursue my own dreams.

It still hurts, though. It always will. But I know I made the right choice. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand. I hope they'll know that I loved them, even though I couldn't keep them.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a fairytale. But it's my story. And I'm trying to make the best of it.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Okay, look, it's a whole thing. It's not like I *intentionally* try to be a terrible lab partner, alright? It just… happens.

It started in biology last semester. Leah and I were paired up for a dissection project. A frog, if you must know. And I… I just couldn't do it. I stared at that frog, and I just… froze. I couldn't bring myself to cut it open. It felt wrong.

Leah was understandably annoyed. She ended up doing all the work, and I just stood there, feeling guilty and useless.

Then it happened again in chemistry. We were supposed to be mixing chemicals and observing reactions, and I just… spaced out. I was thinking about other things, and I accidentally added the wrong ingredient. The whole experiment went wrong.

Leah was *really* annoyed that time. She called me a "deadbeat lab partner," and the name kind of stuck.

It's not that I'm bad at science. I actually like science. It's just that I get easily distracted. And I have a hard time focusing on tasks that I find unpleasant.

And honestly, I'm just not a very practical person. I'm more of a creative person. I'd rather be writing poetry or making films than dissecting frogs or mixing chemicals.

So yeah. That's why I consider myself a deadbeat lab partner. I'm sorry, Leah. I really am. But I just can't help it. I'm a disaster in the lab. It's a known fact. Don't ask me to dissect anything. Please.

(Rolls eyes, already bracing myself) Ugh. Seriously? This is happening *right now*? In the middle of dissecting a frog? People have priorities.

Okay, so, I'm observing this whole thing. The girl, Vanessa (ironically, same name as the woman adopting the baby, which is just… weird), is clearly frustrated because Mark (also ironically, a common name) keeps mansplaining the frog anatomy to her. Like she hasn't taken biology before.

My internal monologue is currently screaming, "Seriously, dude? She's holding the scalpel! She clearly knows what she's doing!"

I'm not one for getting involved in other people's drama, but this is just… infuriating. So, I clear my throat, and in my most deadpan voice, I say, "You know, frogs have a surprisingly complex circulatory system. It's almost as complex as basic respect."

I don't even look at them. I just keep dissecting the frog, like it's the most fascinating thing in the world. 

Then I add, without missing a beat, "Unless you're planning on writing a thesis on frog anatomy, maybe let Vanessa finish her sentence?"

It's not a shout, it's not a yell. It's just… a statement of fact. Delivered with maximum sarcasm.

Usually, that shuts people up. Mark looks flustered, Vanessa gives me a small, grateful smile, and the lab teacher glares at all of us. 

I just shrug and go back to the frog. Honestly, the frog is more interesting than this whole situation. And at least the frog isn't mansplaining anything. It's just… a frog. And sometimes, that's all you need.

(A long, drawn-out sigh. Juno shifts uncomfortably.)

Whoa, hold on. "Hasty abortion?" That's… a really loaded way to put it. And it's not what I'm considering. I'm considering adoption. There's a *huge* difference.

Look, I get it. You're probably trying to understand my situation, but phrasing it like that… it feels really dismissive and judgmental.

I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, let alone raise a whole other human being. I have my own dreams and goals, and I want to pursue them.

And honestly, I don't think I could give a baby the life it deserves right now. I wouldn't be able to provide for it financially, emotionally, or practically. It wouldn't be fair to the baby.

I've thought about all my options. And adoption feels like the best one. It allows me to give the baby a loving home with parents who are ready and able to provide for it. And it allows me to finish school and pursue my own future.

It's not an easy decision. It's heartbreaking, actually. But it's the right one. For everyone involved.

So, please, don't frame it as a "hasty abortion." It's a thoughtful, difficult decision that I'm making with a lot of consideration and support. And it's not something I'm taking lightly.

It's about giving a baby the best possible life, even if that life isn't with me. And that's something I can live with. It's not easy, but it's what I have to do. And I'm trying to be strong about it. Okay?

(Scoffs) Oh. *Finally*. A question of substance. Everyone always asks about the heavy stuff, the existential dread, the adoption. No one appreciates the *important* things in life.

Okay, listen. It's not just that Snow Peak Peach is good. It's that it's *perfect*. It's a delicate balance. It's not overly sweet, like the strawberry. It doesn't try too hard, like the apple. It's just… subtly peachy. Sophisticated, even.

But Snow Peak Peach… it's a little bit of happiness in a bottle. It's a small pleasure that can make a bad day a little bit better.
