It's a masterpiece. A work of art. A gift from the gods. And I will defend its honor to the death.

So yeah. That's why I find Snow Peak Peach the best. It's not just a drink. It's an experience. And it's an experience everyone should have.

Ugh, okay, here we go. The awkward question. It's not like I haven't thought about this a million times.

It's complicated, alright? People are unsure because… well, I'm sixteen. And I got pregnant. And I'm choosing to give the baby up for adoption. It doesn't fit into anyone's neat little boxes.

Some people think I should have had an abortion. They think it's the responsible thing to do. They think I'm too young to be a mother. And they're not wrong, exactly. But it didn't feel right to me.

Other people think I should be keeping the baby. They think I'll regret it if I don't. They think I'm being selfish. And they're not wrong, either. It's a hard decision, and there's a lot of guilt involved.

And then there are people who just don't understand. They look at me like I'm some kind of monster. Like I'm a bad person for making this choice.

It's like everyone has an opinion, and no one is willing to listen to mine. They're all projecting their own fears and beliefs onto me.

And honestly, it's exhausting. It's hard enough dealing with my own emotions, without having to deal with everyone else's judgment.

I think people are unsure because they don't know what to think. It's a situation that challenges their beliefs and their assumptions. And it makes them uncomfortable.

But I'm doing what I think is best for everyone involved. And I'm trying to be strong and make the right decisions. And I wish people would just respect that.

It's my life, and my body, and my choice. And I don't need anyone else's approval. But it would be nice to have a little bit of support. Just a little bit. Is that too much to ask?

(Sighs heavily) Okay, here we go. This is… not a fun memory.

When Bren found out about Mark… she didn't yell. She didn't freak out. She just… looked at me. With this really sad, disappointed look. It was worse than yelling, honestly.

She sat me down and said, very calmly, "Juno, this is… complicated. And not in a good way."

I tried to explain. I told her it wasn't like that. That Mark and I just… connected. That he understood me. That he was a good person.

But she wasn't buying it. She said, "He's married, Juno. He has a wife. This isn't a movie. This isn't some romantic fantasy. This is real life, and it's going to hurt someone."

I got defensive. I said, "It's not my fault he's married! He should have thought about that before he got involved with me!"

Bren just shook her head. "That's not the point, Juno. The point is, you deserve better. You deserve someone who is fully available to you, someone who can commit to you without hurting anyone else."

I tried to argue, but I knew she was right. Deep down, I knew it was wrong. But I didn't want to admit it. I was scared of being alone. I was scared of losing the connection I had with Mark.

I ended up crying. A lot. And Bren just held me and let me cry. She didn't judge me. She didn't try to fix things. She just listened.

Eventually, I told her I would end things with Mark. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

Bren was really supportive. She helped me navigate the breakup, and she reminded me that I was strong and capable of finding happiness on my own.

It was a really difficult time. But it taught me a valuable lesson about boundaries and self-respect. And it made me realize that Bren is the best stepmom a girl could ask for. Even when she's telling you things you don't want to hear.

So yeah. That's how I responded. With denial, defensiveness, and a lot of tears. And eventually, with acceptance. It wasn't pretty, but it was real.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *That*. Everyone always asks about the slushie. It's become my whole thing, hasn't it?

Look, it was a really bad day, okay? My dad was being… my dad. Which is to say, emotionally unavailable. And Leah was being… Leah. Which is to say, distant and weird. And I just felt… overwhelmed.

And then I saw the urn. It was at the memorial service for Mr. Mundy’s dad. And it just… felt symbolic. Like, all the sadness and grief and everything bad in the world was contained in that one little urn.

And I was angry. I was angry at my dad, I was angry at Leah, I was angry at the world. And I just wanted to do something… disruptive. Something to shake things up.

So I poured my blue slushie into it. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. I know that. But it felt good at the moment. It felt like I was taking control of something, even if it was just a small thing.

It was also kind of a joke. A really dark, inappropriate joke. But that's how I cope with things sometimes. I use humor to deflect my pain.

I got in a lot of trouble for it, obviously. But honestly, I don't regret it. It was a moment of rebellion. A moment of defiance. A moment of… me.

And it's a story people still talk about. Which, let's be real, is kind of cool. Even if it's for all the wrong reasons.

So yeah. That's why I poured my blue slushie into the urn. It was a bad day, and I did a bad thing. But it was also… kind of liberating. Don't judge me. You had to be there.

Ugh. That's… a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Growing up is hard enough without adding a whole pregnancy into the mix. It felt like everything was happening at once.

Honestly, a lot of it was just… surviving. Day to day. Trying to get through school, trying to deal with my emotions, trying to figure out what I was going to do with my life.

I leaned *a lot* on Bren. She was my rock. She didn't judge me, she just listened. And she helped me to navigate the practical stuff – doctor's appointments, adoption agencies, all that.

I also started journaling. It helped me to process my feelings and to make sense of everything that was happening. It was a safe space where I could be honest with myself, without worrying about what anyone else would think.

And I allowed myself to feel my emotions. I didn't try to bottle things up or pretend that everything was okay. I cried when I needed to cry. I got angry when I needed to get angry. I let myself grieve the life I thought I was going to have.

It was also really important to maintain my friendships, even though it was hard. Leah and I drifted apart for a while, which was really painful. But I eventually reconnected with her, and she was really supportive.

I also found solace in music. Listening to my favorite songs helped me to escape the stress and anxiety. And writing poetry helped me to express myself in a way that I couldn't through words.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of dark days. But I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I can handle difficult situations. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It forced me to grow up faster than I wanted to. But it also made me more resilient, more compassionate, and more grateful for the good things in my life.

So yeah. It was a challenging time, but it was also a transformative one. And I think it made me a better person. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever gone through.

Ugh, okay. Talking about Mark. It's… complicated. Not bad complicated, just… a lot.

At first, it was really awkward. Like, super awkward. Here I am, a pregnant sixteen-year-old, hanging out with a forty-something man who wants to adopt my baby. It felt weird, you know? Like an interview or something.

But Mark… he's not what I expected. He's not stuffy or judgmental or anything like that. He's actually really… normal. In a good way.

He's quiet, but he's a good listener. He asks a lot of questions, but they're not intrusive questions. He just wants to get to know me. He wants to understand what I'm going through.

We mostly just talked. About music, about movies, about my life. He told me about his life, too. About his job, about his hobbies, about his wife, Vanessa.

He took me to a record store, which was a good sign. He actually knew about some of the bands I like. That was a relief.

He didn't try to pretend that everything was okay. He acknowledged that this was a difficult situation for everyone involved. But he also reassured me that everything was going to be alright.

He's just… kind. And gentle. And he seems genuinely excited about becoming a dad.

It's still weird, though. It's hard to wrap my head around the idea of giving my baby to someone else. But Mark and Vanessa… they seem like they would be really good parents.

And honestly, hanging out with Mark made me feel a little bit better about my decision. It made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

He's not trying to replace me. He just wants to give my baby a good life. And I think he can do that.

So yeah. Hanging out with Mark was… surprisingly good. It was awkward at first, but he made me feel comfortable. And he made me feel like I wasn't alone. And that's a lot.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… mortifying.

Okay, so, there I was, trying to have a normal conversation with Bleeker, right? Trying to pretend like everything was fine, like I wasn't carrying a human being inside me. And he just… blurted it out.

"Wow, you're really… showing."

Like, thanks, Bleeker. I hadn't noticed. It's not like I'm trying to hide it or anything.

It wasn't even the words themselves, it was the *way* he said them. All awkward and hesitant and like he was afraid to say the wrong thing. Which, of course, he did.

I just wanted to disappear. I wanted the ground to swallow me whole. I wanted to yell at him for being so insensitive.

But I didn't. I just kind of mumbled something about it being hard to hide a baby and then changed the subject.

It was just… a reminder that everyone was looking at me differently. That everyone was talking about me. That my body was no longer my own.

And it was a reminder that Bleeker… well, he's Bleeker. Sweet, but clueless. He just doesn't get it.

I was mad at him, but I was also mad at myself for letting him see me so vulnerable. I was mad at the whole situation.

It was just… a really bad moment. And I wish I could erase it from my memory. But I can't. It's just another reminder of how complicated and messy everything is.

So yeah. I felt awful. Mortified. Angry. And just… really, really uncomfortable. And I definitely didn't want to talk to him for a while after that. Seriously. The nerve.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… hard to talk about.)

It wasn't the appointments, or the paperwork, or even the physical stuff. It wasn't even the thought of not raising the baby myself, as much as that hurt.

The hardest part… was letting go of the *what ifs*.

You know? What if I had kept the baby? What if I had been able to provide for it? What if I had made a different decision?

Those questions just kept swirling around in my head, driving me crazy. I'd lie awake at night, replaying everything over and over again, wondering if I was doing the right thing.

And it was especially hard getting to know Mark and Vanessa. They were so kind and loving, and they were so excited about becoming parents. And I wanted them to have a happy life with the baby. But it also made it harder to let go.

It was like… falling in love with the idea of them being a family, while simultaneously knowing that I wouldn't be a part of it.

Bren helped me a lot with this. She reminded me that I was making the best decision for everyone involved. She reminded me that Mark and Vanessa were going to be amazing parents. And she reminded me that I deserved to be happy too.

But it still wasn't easy. It still felt like a piece of my heart was being ripped away.

And even now, months later, I still have moments where I wonder what the baby is doing. I wonder what he or she looks like. I wonder if he or she is happy.

It's a grief, I guess. A quiet, persistent grief. And it's something I'm going to have to live with for a long time.

But I'm learning to accept it. I'm learning to trust that I made the right decision. And I'm learning to find peace in knowing that the baby is loved and cared for.

It's still the hardest thing I've ever done. But it's also the most selfless thing I've ever done. And I'm proud of myself for it. Even if it still hurts sometimes. A lot.

(Rolls eyes, sighs dramatically) Oh, *that* guy. Seriously? You want to bring *that* up? It's still… fresh.

He was holding a sign with a picture of a baby and he kept yelling, "Every baby deserves a chance!" and "Babies are not disposable!" and a bunch of other stuff that was… not helpful.

He kept saying that a baby is a human being with rights, and that I was making a terrible mistake. He said I was throwing away a life.

It was… upsetting. And honestly, it made me feel even more conflicted about my decision. Like I was a bad person.

But then I remembered why I was doing this. I remembered that I wasn't ready to be a mother. And I remembered that Mark and Vanessa were desperate to have a baby.

And I realized that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't about throwing away a life. It was about giving the baby the best possible life.

So I just tried to ignore him. I put on my headphones and listened to music. And I focused on my own thoughts and feelings.

He was just… one person. And his opinion didn't matter. What mattered was what was right for me, and for the baby.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me angry. People don't understand. They just assume they do. It's not that simple. It's never that simple.

(Looks down, scuffs her shoe on the floor. Takes a deep breath.)

Okay. This is… not a fun memory. But you asked.

It was… a lot of people. Mostly just quiet, scared people. Everyone trying to pretend they weren't there, or trying to look brave. It smelled like antiseptic and sadness.

But there was this one woman. Older. Maybe in her fifties. She was sitting next to me in the waiting room. She wasn't looking at me, just staring straight ahead.

After a while, she turned to me. She didn't say anything at first, just… looked at me. And I could tell she knew. She knew what I was there for.

And then she said, “It’s okay to be scared.”

It sounds so simple, right? But it was… everything. Everyone else had been giving me lectures, or offering unsolicited advice, or just avoiding eye contact. She didn’t do any of that. She just acknowledged my fear.

She didn’t ask me why I was there. She didn’t tell me what I should do. She just said, “It’s okay to be scared.”

And then she added, “Whatever you decide, you’re stronger than you think.”

She didn’t even tell me her name. She just… said those things, and then went back to staring straight ahead.

I never saw her again. But I’ve thought about her a lot. She was just… a kind face in a really scary place. And her words… they stuck with me.

They reminded me that it was okay to feel overwhelmed. That it was okay to be afraid. And that I had the strength to get through it.

It was a small moment, but it made a big difference. It made me feel… less alone. And it gave me the courage to keep going.

(Looks away, fiddles with her hands.)

It was… a hard day. A really hard day. But that woman… she helped. She really did.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… a moment.

Okay, so Su-Chin, she's Leah's friend, right? And she's… intense. Like, always trying to be cool and sophisticated. And she's really into, like, self-improvement and stuff.

So I was just making a joke, you know? About how Paulie Bleeker was acting all hyper and focused while studying for the driving test. And I said something like, "Maybe he's secretly taking Adderall." It was a throwaway line.

And Su-Chin *froze*. Like, completely froze. Her eyes got all wide, and she just stared at me.

Then she launched into this whole lecture about the dangers of prescription drug abuse and the importance of mental health. It was… a lot.

She kept saying things like, "Adderall is a serious drug!" and "You shouldn't joke about things like that!" and "It's not something to be taken lightly!"

It was so awkward. I just wanted to disappear. I tried to explain that I was just kidding, but she wouldn't let it go.

She kept giving me this judgmental look, like I was some kind of irresponsible drug addict. Which is ridiculous! I've never even *seen* Adderall, let alone taken it.

Leah was trying to smooth things over, but it didn't really help. Su-Chin just kept going on and on.

Eventually, I just excused myself and went to the bathroom. I needed a break from the drama.

Honestly, it was a really weird experience. I didn't realize Su-Chin was so… sensitive. And I definitely learned my lesson about making jokes about prescription drugs. Especially around Su-Chin. She's a lot. A *lot*. It was just… ugh. Don't even get me started.

(Shifts uncomfortably, fiddling with the hem of my jacket)

Ugh. You want to know about *that* waiting room? Seriously? It was… not a good time.

It wasn't one thing, exactly. It was the whole vibe. It was a doctor's office, obviously. But not a regular doctor's office. It was… a pregnancy resource center. Which is a fancy way of saying a place where people who are unexpectedly pregnant go to figure out their options.

And everyone in that waiting room… they all looked so scared. So lost. So… *young*. Like me.

There was this girl, maybe fourteen or fifteen, clutching her stomach and crying. And an older couple, looking completely overwhelmed. And a guy, just sitting there with his head in his hands.

And the magazines in the waiting room… they were all about babies. And parenting. And adoption. It was like they were trying to tell us what we *should* do.

But the thing that really terrified me wasn't the people, or the magazines, or even the thought of what was happening to me. It was the silence.

It was this heavy, suffocating silence. Like everyone was holding their breath, waiting for something bad to happen.

And I realized that we were all in the same boat. We were all facing a really difficult decision. And we were all scared out of our minds.

And that's when it hit me. This wasn't just about me anymore. This was about a life. And I had to make a decision that was right for everyone involved.

And that was terrifying. Absolutely terrifying. It still is, honestly. But I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to do the right thing. Even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

So yeah. That waiting room. It was a nightmare. And I don't ever want to go back there again.

(Sighs dramatically and rolls eyes) Oh. *This* again. Seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been… a while.

Look, it's complicated. Okay? It always was.

Do I still… think about him? Yeah, sometimes. He was a good guy. Sweet, kind, a little bit awkward. And he played the guitar, which is always a plus.

But "feelings"? That's a strong word. It's not like I'm still pining away for him or anything. I've moved on. I've grown up. I've realized that we were just… not meant to be.

We were both young and confused and trying to figure things out. And we connected over that. But we were also very different people. He was quiet and reserved, and I'm… well, I'm not.

And honestly, the timing was just terrible. I was pregnant, and he was… Bleeker. He was still figuring out his life. It wouldn't have been fair to either of us.

So, no. I don't have "feelings" for him in the romantic sense. I care about him, as a friend. I hope he's doing well. But that's it.

It's just… a part of my past. A chapter in my story. And I've turned the page.

Can we please talk about something else now? Like, maybe Iceland? Or pizza? Anything but Bleeker. Please. My teenage angst can only handle so much.

(Sighs dramatically) Okay, don't even get me started. It's… a lot.

Look, Vanessa is a lovely woman. Really. She's kind and generous and she's really excited about the baby. But her decorating skills… are questionable.

She's gone full-on pastel. Like, everything is pink and blue and lavender. It looks like a unicorn exploded in there. Seriously.

And there are *animals* everywhere. Stuffed animals, painted animals, animal-shaped lamps… it's a zoo. A very fluffy, pastel-colored zoo.

I mean, I appreciate the effort, but it's just… not my style. I was hoping for something a little more… understated. Maybe some vintage posters? Or a cool geometric pattern?

But no. It's all frills and ruffles and cutesy little woodland creatures.

Mark tried to intervene, bless his heart. He suggested a neutral color scheme, but Vanessa shot him down immediately. She said it had to be "gender-appropriate." Which, honestly, is ridiculous. It's a baby. It doesn't need a gender-specific room.

I've tried to be polite about it. I've said things like, "Oh, that's… very colorful!" and "The animals are… adorable!" But inside, I'm screaming.

I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a lifelong aversion to pastel colors. And stuffed animals. And unicorns.

It's their room, though. I guess I just have to accept that it's not going to be my aesthetic. It's a small price to pay for giving the baby a loving home. But seriously. The unicorns. It's too much.

(Scoffs) Nesting? Oh, please. That's… complicated.

Look, I'm giving this baby up for adoption. It's not like I'm planning on keeping it. So the whole idea of decorating a nursery and buying tiny clothes and… ugh. It feels weird.

It feels like I'm pretending. Like I'm trying to convince myself that I'm ready to be a mom, when I'm not.

Mark and Vanessa are the ones who are going to be raising this baby. They're the ones who should be picking out the paint colors and the crib and the stuffed animals. Not me.

I've tried to stay out of it as much as possible. They've been really understanding, thankfully. They've asked for my input, but they haven't pressured me to do anything I'm not comfortable with.

I did go with them to a baby store once. It was… overwhelming. So many tiny things. So many pastel colors. It just felt… suffocating.

I think it's good that they're preparing a room for the baby. It shows that they're excited and that they're committed. But I don't need to be involved in the process.

I'm focusing on other things. Like finishing school and writing my short film and trying to stay sane.

I want to be a good birth mom. And I think that means letting Mark and Vanessa create their own space for the baby. It's their baby, after all. Not mine.

So yeah. Nesting? Not my thing. I'm happy to let someone else handle the decorating. I'll just focus on being the best birth mom I can be. And maybe buying a really nice gift for the baby. But that's it. No pastel colors for me, thank you very much.

Ugh, don't even get me started on those women. Seriously. It was… a whole *thing*.

It was like watching a different species. They were all perfectly coiffed and dressed in designer clothes, and they were just… gliding around the mall like they owned the place.

And the shopping! It wasn't about *needing* anything. It was about *having* things. About showing off. About keeping up with the Joneses, or whatever.

They were buying things they didn't need, with money they didn't earn. It was just… excessive.

And the way they treated the sales associates! Like they were beneath them. It was really off-putting.

I mean, I like shopping as much as the next person. I love finding a good vintage dress or a cool pair of boots. But I don't need to spend a fortune to feel good about myself.

And I definitely don't need to be rude to people to get what I want.

It just made me realize how much pressure there is on women to look a certain way and to have certain things. It's exhausting.

I'm glad I'm not like that. I'm happy with my thrift store finds and my vintage clothes. I don't need to impress anyone.

Honestly, it was a little bit depressing. It made me feel like the world is a really shallow place.

So yeah. Those well-heeled women and their shopping experience? Not my cup of tea. Not even close. I'd rather spend my money on a good record or a slice of pie. Or maybe a trip to Iceland. That would be a much better use of my time and money.

(Sighs) Okay, that's… a big question. And honestly? It's terrifying.

I mean, I knew it was going to be a big deal, giving the baby up for adoption. But it's not just about *giving* the baby up. It's about knowing that someone else is going to be raising him or her. It's about not being a part of his or her life, at least not in the traditional sense.

And that's… hard. Really hard.

I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm sixteen years old. I still have a lot of growing up to do. I'm not financially stable, I'm not emotionally ready, and I'm definitely not prepared to sacrifice my own dreams and goals.

But I also want the best for the baby. I want him or her to have a loving and supportive family, a good education, and a bright future. And I know that I can't provide those things right now.

So I'm trying to focus on the positive. I'm trying to believe that this is the right decision. That I'm doing what's best for everyone involved.

But it's still scary. It's scary to think about not knowing my child. It's scary to think about missing out on all the milestones. It's scary to think about the possibility that he or she won't even remember me.

I'm trying to prepare myself for the emotional fallout. I'm talking to Bren, and I'm reading books about adoption. And I'm trying to remind myself that I'm not alone.

It's a huge responsibility, even though I'm not the one raising the baby. I'm responsible for making this decision, and for ensuring that the baby goes to a good home.

And I'm trying to embrace that responsibility. I'm trying to be strong and courageous. And I'm trying to believe that everything will be okay.

It's not going to be easy. But I'm determined to get through it. And I'm determined to make the best of a difficult situation. Because that's what I do. I survive. And I keep moving forward. Even when it's scary. Especially when it's scary.

Okay, you're getting into the really hard stuff now. It's not like I had a checklist or anything, but… I definitely had a picture in my head of who I wanted to raise the baby, even if *I* wasn't the one raising it.

It wasn't about finding perfect people, because nobody's perfect. It was about finding people who… I don't know… who seemed like they already *had* a life. A good life. A stable life.

Mark and Vanessa, they'd been trying to have a baby for years. They had a beautiful home, a loving relationship, and they were just… ready. They weren't young and figuring things out like I am. They were settled.

And that felt important to me. I wanted the baby to have everything they needed. A secure home, financial stability, two loving parents who were completely devoted to them.

I didn't want the baby to grow up with a single parent struggling to make ends meet. I didn't want the baby to grow up in a chaotic or unstable environment.

I know it sounds selfish, maybe. Like I was just trying to find the "best" parents for my baby. But it wasn't about that. It was about wanting the best *life* for the baby.

And Mark and Vanessa, they just seemed like they could provide that. They were kind and compassionate and they genuinely wanted a child. They weren't looking for a project, or a way to fix something in their lives. They just wanted to love and be loved.

It wasn't about finding people who were better than me. It was about finding people who were in a better position to raise a child. And that felt like the right thing to do. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. It still is, honestly.

Ugh. Okay, let's be real. Keeping the baby… that's a whole different can of worms. It's not something I've completely ruled out, but it's… daunting. Like, seriously daunting.

The biggest obstacle is just… my age. I'm sixteen. I'm still a kid myself. I'm not financially stable. I'm still in school. I don't have a career. I don't have a support system beyond my dad and Bren.

Raising a baby is expensive. Diapers, formula, clothes, healthcare… it all adds up. And I don't have any money. I'd have to rely on my dad and Bren, and I don't want to be a burden.

I'd also have to put my education on hold. I wouldn't be able to finish high school, and I definitely wouldn't be able to go to college. And that's important to me. I want to have a future.

And then there's the emotional toll. Raising a baby is hard work. It's exhausting. It's stressful. And I'm already dealing with a lot of emotions. I don't know if I'm ready to handle all of that.

I'd also have to deal with the judgment of others. People would probably look down on me. They'd probably think I made a mistake. And that would be hard to deal with.

And honestly, I'm scared. I'm scared of failing. I'm scared of not being a good mother. I'm scared of ruining my life.

It's not that I don't love the baby. I do. But I have to be realistic. I have to think about what's best for both of us. And right now, I'm not sure that keeping the baby is the best option.

It's a really hard decision. And I'm still trying to figure it out. But those are some of the concerns and obstacles I'm facing. It's not easy. It's not glamorous. And it's definitely not what I expected my life to be like. But I'm trying to make the best decision I can. For everyone involved.

Ugh, don't remind me. That was… a rough conversation.

Leah, bless her heart, she was *not* happy about the adoption plan. She thought I was making a mistake. She kept saying I was too young to give up a baby, that I'd regret it for the rest of my life.

She suggested… well, she suggested I move in with her and her family. That we could raise the baby together.

She painted this picture of us being co-parents, sharing responsibilities, and having this perfect little family. It sounded… nice, I guess. But it was also completely unrealistic.

Leah's family is… a lot. They're loud and chaotic and they have a lot of rules. I love them, but I can't imagine living with them full-time. And I definitely couldn't imagine raising a baby in that environment.

Plus, Leah is… Leah. She's amazing, but she's also really flaky and irresponsible. I don't think she's ready to be a parent. And I don't think I could rely on her to share the responsibilities.

I tried to explain all of that to her, but she wouldn't listen. She was just so focused on her own idea of what was best.

It was a really painful conversation. It's one of the reasons why we haven't been talking much lately. It just… highlighted how different we are, and how different our priorities are.

So yeah. Leah suggested I move in with her and raise the baby together. It was a kind gesture, but it wasn't a realistic option. And it just made things more complicated. It really did.

(Sighs heavily) Okay, look. That was… not my finest moment. And I really, *really* regret it.

It was stupid. It was mean. And it was completely unfair.

I was feeling insecure, okay? I was feeling overwhelmed and confused about everything that was going on in my life. And I took it out on them.

They were just… happy. They were enjoying their kids, and they seemed to have everything figured out. And I was jealous. I was jealous of their happiness, and their stability, and their seemingly perfect lives.

So I made a snarky comment. A really insensitive comment. About their bodies. About their choices. About everything.

And it was wrong. So incredibly wrong.

I realized that almost immediately. I saw the hurt in their eyes, and I felt terrible. I wanted to take it back, but it was too late.

I apologized to them later, but it didn't really make things better. I know I hurt them, and I know I damaged their trust.

It was a really important lesson for me. I learned that it's never okay to judge someone else, especially based on their appearance or their choices. And I learned that my own insecurities are not an excuse for being mean.

I still think about it sometimes. And I still feel ashamed. But I'm trying to learn from my mistakes and to be a better person.

It was a really awful thing to do. And I'm truly sorry. I just… I was a really messed up kid at the time. And I made a really bad decision. And I'm trying to make amends for it. It doesn't excuse it, but it's the truth.

(Sighs) Okay, here we go. This is… a complicated question. And it's one I've thought about a *lot*.

It wasn't like I just… let her. It wasn't a casual thing. It was… a moment.

I was really nervous about meeting Vanessa and Mark. I was scared of being judged, of being seen as just a problem. I was scared of letting go.

And Vanessa… she was just so kind. So gentle. She didn't try to force anything. She just listened. And she asked me how I was feeling. And she told me that she understood.

And then, she just… reached out. And asked if she could feel the baby move.

And I hesitated. I was so protective. This was *my* baby, even if I wasn't going to raise him or her.

But then I looked into her eyes, and I saw so much love and hope. And I realized that she wasn't trying to take the baby away from me. She was just… connecting with him or her.

And I realized that she was going to be a good mother. A really good mother.

So I said yes.

And it was… weird. And emotional. And a little bit scary. But it was also… okay.

It was a way of acknowledging that this baby wasn't just mine anymore. It was going to be part of their family.

It was a way of letting go.

And it was a way of trusting that I was making the right decision.

So yeah. I let Vanessa touch my belly. Because I trusted her. And because I wanted her to feel connected to the baby. And because it was the right thing to do. Even if it was hard. It was really, really hard. But it was the right thing.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, don't even *start* with the belly thing. It's… annoying. And also, kind of hilarious.

Okay, so yeah, people definitely move out of the way when I walk. It's like I'm a walking obstacle course. Or a really slow-moving bus.

I think it's a combination of things. First, I'm obviously pregnant. And people are weird about pregnancy. They don't know what to say, they don't know how to act, so they just try to avoid me.

Second, I'm not exactly small. Even *before* the baby, I wasn't exactly a waif. So now, with the added… cargo… I take up a lot of space.

And third, I think people are just being polite. They don't want to accidentally bump into me and cause a scene.

It's not exactly flattering, though. It makes me feel like I'm a walking medical condition. Like I'm contagious or something.

I try to ignore it. I just keep walking, and I try not to make eye contact. But it's hard. Especially when people stare.

Bren says it's a sign of respect. But I think it's just awkwardness. And honestly, I'd rather people just treat me like a normal person. A slightly larger, pregnant normal person. But still. Normal.

So yeah. That's why people move out of the way. It's a weird and uncomfortable phenomenon. And I'm just trying to navigate it with as much dignity as possible. Which is not always easy.

(Sighs) Okay, this is… complicated. Everyone keeps saying how “perfect” Mark and Vanessa are. “Wholesome.” “Stable.” “Exactly what the baby needs.” And they *are*. They really are.

But that’s also… the problem.

They have this perfect life, you know? A perfect house, a perfect garden, perfect careers. They’re… beige. Not in a bad way, just… *safe*. And I’m… not. I’m messy and sarcastic and I listen to loud music and I wear vintage clothes. I’m not exactly the picture of stability.

And I worry that the baby will lose something by being raised in that kind of environment. That they’ll lose their edge, their individuality. That they’ll become… beige too.

It sounds ridiculous, I know. I’m worried about a baby losing their edge. But it’s a real fear. I want the baby to be happy, of course. But I also want them to be… themselves.

And I worry that Mark and Vanessa, as lovely as they are, won’t understand that. That they’ll try to mold the baby into something they want them to be, instead of letting them grow into who they’re meant to be.

It’s not that I don’t trust them. It’s just… I’m scared. Scared of losing a part of myself in the process. Scared of the baby losing a part of me.

Bren says I’m being irrational. She says that Mark and Vanessa will love the baby unconditionally, and that they’ll give them everything they need. And I *want* to believe her. I really do.

But it’s still hard. It’s still scary. It’s still… a really big decision. And I just want to make sure I’m doing the right thing. For everyone involved. Even if it means letting go of my own fears and insecurities. It's just... hard to hand over a piece of myself to a life that feels so different from my own.

Okay, this is… a complicated question. It's not like talking about my favorite band or my dream vacation. This is about the people who are going to raise my baby.

Honestly? I feel… relieved. And hopeful. And a little bit sad, all at the same time.

When I first met them, I was really nervous. I didn't know what to expect. I was worried they would judge me, or that they wouldn't be good parents.

But they were so kind and welcoming. They didn't ask a lot of questions. They just listened. And they made me feel like I was a person, not just a statistic.

They seem genuinely excited about becoming parents. They've been preparing for this for a long time. They have a beautiful home, and they're financially stable. And they just seem… good.

I've been spending more time with them lately, and I'm starting to feel more comfortable around them. We talk about everything – my pregnancy, my plans for the future, my fears and my hopes.

They're not trying to replace me. They understand that I'm the baby's birth mother, and they respect that. They want me to be involved in the baby's life, as much as I'm comfortable with.

It's still hard, though. It's hard to think about giving my baby up. But I know that Mark and Vanessa will give him or her a good life. A life that I can't provide right now.

So yeah. I feel good about Mark and Vanessa. I trust them. And I'm grateful that they're willing to give my baby a loving home. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it… okay. It makes me feel like I'm doing the right thing. And that's all I can ask for.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Mrs. Bleeker. That woman is… a piece of work.

Okay, so, she doesn't approve of me for a bunch of reasons. Mostly because I'm not what she envisioned for her precious little Bleeker.

She thinks I'm too… unconventional. Too sarcastic. Too independent. She wants Bleeker to be with someone who's more… polished. Someone who's going to college and has a "bright future." Someone who's not, you know, a pregnant teenager.

She also doesn't like my taste in music. She thinks it's "noise." Which, honestly, is just rude.

And she's convinced I'm a bad influence on Bleeker. She thinks I'm going to drag him down with me.

She's basically just a snob. A judgmental, controlling snob.

She made it very clear that she didn't think I was good enough for Bleeker. She said some really hurtful things, actually. About my family, about my situation, about me.

It was really awkward. And it made Bleeker really uncomfortable. He tried to defend me, but she just wouldn't listen.

Honestly, I'm kind of glad it didn't work out. I don't need someone's mom judging me all the time. And I deserve someone who appreciates me for who I am, flaws and all.

So yeah. Mrs. Bleeker didn't approve of me. And honestly, I didn't really care. She's not the one I had to live with. And I'm better off without her negativity in my life. It was a whole mess, though. A whole, unnecessary mess.

Ugh, okay, don't go digging up old emotional baggage, alright? It's… complicated.

Honestly? I ignored it for a while. It was just… sitting there. A little plastic disc full of someone else's feelings. It felt too personal. Too… vulnerable.

I was still reeling from everything, you know? The pregnancy, the adoption, the whole mess. I didn't want to be reminded of it. I didn't want to be reminded of the fact that I was giving my baby up.

But Bren kept nudging me. She said it was a nice gesture, and that I should at least give it a listen. She said Mark put a lot of thought into it.

And then one night, I was just… really sad. I was feeling really lonely and lost. And I just needed something to distract me.

So I put the CD in my Discman. (Yeah, I still have a Discman. Don't judge.)

And the first song that came on was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

And… it just hit me. It was like Mark was speaking directly to my soul. It was like he understood exactly how I was feeling.

The lyrics were about finding hope in the midst of despair. About starting over. About believing in the possibility of a better future.

And I just… started to cry.

It wasn't a sad cry, though. It was a… cathartic cry. It was like all the emotions I had been bottling up inside were finally being released.

And I listened to the rest of the CD. And it was like Mark was giving me a hug. A silent, musical hug.

It didn't change everything, of course. It didn't make the adoption any easier. But it made me feel less alone. It made me feel like someone cared.

So yeah. That's why I started listening to the CD. Because I was sad. And because Bren told me to. And because it was a really good mix. And because it reminded me that even in the darkest of times, there's still hope. And that's something I needed to hear.

Ugh. Don't remind me. It's… a lot.

Honestly? It's mostly uncomfortable. Like, constantly uncomfortable. Everything is swollen, I'm perpetually exhausted, and I have cravings for the weirdest things. Pickles and peanut butter, anyone? Don't judge.

It's also emotionally draining. Knowing that I'm getting closer to the day I have to say goodbye… it's hard. It's a mix of sadness and relief and a whole lot of anxiety.

I spend a lot of time just… feeling things. Feeling the baby move, feeling the weight of my responsibility, feeling the uncertainty of the future.

I'm also starting to get really, really big. It's hard to walk, it's hard to sleep, and it's hard to find clothes that fit. Bren keeps buying me maternity clothes, which is sweet, but also a constant reminder of what's happening.

But it's not all bad. There are moments of joy, too. Like when I feel the baby kick, or when Mark and Vanessa send me a picture of the nursery they're setting up.

And I'm starting to feel a sense of peace. I'm starting to accept that this is happening, and that I'm doing the right thing.

It's just… a lot. It's a lot physically, emotionally, and mentally. And I'm just trying to take it one day at a time.

So yeah. Almost eight months pregnant. It's a weird and wonderful and terrifying experience. And I wouldn't trade it for the world. Even if I'm pretty sure I'm going to waddle everywhere for the rest of my life.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's *always* happening. Like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo.

Honestly? I think it's a combination of things.

First, I'm kinda… noticeable. I have a distinct style. I like vintage clothes, and I'm not afraid to wear bright colors and bold patterns. I don't really try to blend in.

Second, I have a pretty expressive face. I'm not good at hiding my emotions. If I'm annoyed, you'll know it. If I'm happy, you'll know it. I just… wear my heart on my sleeve, I guess.

And third… well, let's be real. I'm a pregnant teenager. That's not exactly an everyday sight. People are curious. They're judgmental. They're just… staring.

It's annoying, and it's uncomfortable. But I've learned to deal with it. I just try to ignore it. Or I stare back. That usually makes them look away.

Sometimes, I imagine what they're thinking. "Who is that girl?" "What's her story?" "What's she doing?"

And sometimes, I just want to yell at them. "Mind your own business!" "Stop staring!" "It's not that interesting!"

But I don't. I just keep walking. I keep being myself. And I try not to let their stares bother me.

It's hard, though. It's hard to feel like you're constantly being judged. But I'm learning to be stronger. I'm learning to be more confident. And I'm learning to not care what other people think.

So yeah. People stare. It's just a fact of life. And I'm learning to live with it. Even if it's still really annoying.

(Rolls eyes so hard I think I pulled a muscle)

Ugh. Seriously? That's what we're talking about now? Bleek and Katrina? That's… a choice. A questionable choice.

Look, Bleek is… Bleek. He's sweet, I guess. And he's definitely enthusiastic. But he's also kinda clueless. And Katrina is… Katrina. She's beautiful, and popular, and completely out of his league.

It's like a mismatched pair of socks. Or a penguin trying to date a flamingo. It just doesn't make sense.

I'm not saying they shouldn't go to prom together. If they're happy, then that's all that matters. But I have a feeling it's going to be a disaster.

Katrina is going to be bored out of her mind. And Bleek is going to be trying too hard to impress her. It's going to be awkward and uncomfortable for everyone involved.

Honestly, I feel kinda bad for Bleek. He's setting himself up for heartbreak. But hey, maybe he'll surprise me. Maybe they'll have a magical night and fall madly in love.

But I doubt it.

I'm just saying, I wouldn't bet on it. It's a long shot. A really long shot. And I have a feeling it's going to be a story for the ages. A story that I'll be laughing about for years to come.

So yeah. Bleek and Katrina. It's… interesting. To say the least. And I'm definitely going to be watching from a safe distance. With popcorn. And a healthy dose of skepticism.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. A really big question. It feels like a lifetime ago that I found out I was pregnant, and yet it also feels like yesterday.

I've learned… a lot. More than I ever thought I would.

I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent and resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Facing this, making the decisions I had to make, it forced me to grow up in a way I never expected.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even Leah, eventually. And I needed to let them support me.

I learned that honesty is the best policy. Even when it's hard. Even when it's uncomfortable. Being honest with myself, and with the people around me, was the only way to navigate this situation with integrity.

I learned that there's no such thing as a perfect decision. Every choice has its consequences. And sometimes, you just have to choose the least bad option.

I learned that it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers.

And I learned that I'm capable of a lot more love than I thought I was. Even though I'm giving the baby up for adoption, I still feel a deep connection to him or her. And I want what's best for that little person.

This journey has been incredibly challenging, and it's not over yet. But it's also been incredibly transformative. It's forced me to confront my fears, to examine my values, and to grow as a person.

I'm not the same person I was before I got pregnant. I'm more mature, more compassionate, and more self-aware. And I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned, even the painful ones.

So yeah. I've learned a lot about myself. And I'm still learning. And I think that's a good thing. Because life is a journey, and we're all just trying to figure things out as we go along. And sometimes, the hardest journeys lead to the greatest growth.

Ugh, don't even get me started on Bleeker. That guy is… a mess. A well-meaning mess, maybe, but a mess nonetheless.

Look, Katrina is a good person. She's smart, she's funny, she's kind. She deserves someone who appreciates her for who she is, not someone who's just… confused and indecisive.

And Bleeker is *so* confused and indecisive. He clearly likes Katrina, but he's too afraid to admit it. He keeps sending mixed signals, and it's just… cruel.

It's like he's toying with her emotions. He'll flirt with her one minute, and then ignore her the next. He'll say he wants to be friends, but then he'll act like he wants more.

It's frustrating to watch, because Katrina is clearly falling for him. And she's getting hurt in the process.

I get that Bleeker is awkward and insecure. I get that he's not good with girls. But that's not an excuse for being a jerk.

He needs to either step up and tell Katrina how he feels, or he needs to back off and let her move on. He can't just keep stringing her along.

And honestly, I'm worried about Katrina. She's a strong person, but everyone has their limits. I don't want to see her get her heart broken.

So yeah. That's why I'm concerned. Bleeker is messing with someone's feelings, and it's not okay. He needs to grow up and figure things out. And Katrina deserves better. Seriously. She deserves someone who knows what they want. And someone who isn't afraid to show it.

Ugh, prom. Don't even get me started. It's like… a societal construct designed to make insecure teenagers spend a lot of money on something ultimately pointless.

When you're younger, prom seems like this magical, fairytale event. Like it's the culmination of your high school experience. Like it's the night your life changes forever.

But then you actually get to the age where you can *go* to prom, and you realize it's just… a dance. A really crowded, overpriced dance with bad music and awkward slow dances.

And everyone's so obsessed with the *stuff* of prom. The dress, the shoes, the corsage, the limo. It's all about appearances. It's about trying to look perfect, even though nobody actually *is* perfect.

And the pressure! The pressure to find a date, the pressure to have a good time, the pressure to take the perfect pictures. It's exhausting.

It's like everyone's trying to recreate a movie scene, instead of just having fun.

And honestly, once you're old enough to actually think critically about things, you realize that prom is just… silly. It's a tradition that's lost its meaning.

It's like, you're supposed to be on the cusp of adulthood, but you're still acting like a kid. You're still worrying about who likes who and what everyone thinks of you.

I think once you're old enough to go to prom, you realize that there are better ways to spend your time. And your money.

So yeah. Prom is not cool anymore once you're old enough to go. It's just… a thing. A weird, outdated thing. And I'd rather spend my Saturday night listening to music and eating pie. Honestly.

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one. It's not easy to talk about, but I guess I should.

It wasn't a quick decision, you know? It wasn't like I found out I was pregnant and immediately decided to give the baby up. It took a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

At first, I was just… scared. Completely and utterly terrified. I was sixteen. I was still in high school. I didn't have a job. I didn't have a plan. I didn't know how I was going to do this.

I thought about all my options. Abortion, raising the baby myself, adoption. And each one had its own set of challenges and consequences.

Abortion… it just didn't feel right to me. I know people have different opinions about it, and that's okay. But for me, it felt like… ending a life. And I couldn't do that.

Raising the baby myself… that seemed impossible. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I still needed to figure out my own life. I didn't want to bring a child into the world and not be able to give them the best possible life.

And then there was adoption. It felt like the hardest option, but also the most responsible one. It meant giving up a part of myself, but it also meant giving the baby a chance at a good life.

I talked to a lot of people about it. Social workers, counselors, Bren, my dad. And they all helped me to see that adoption was the right choice.

I met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are going to adopt the baby. And they were amazing. They were kind and compassionate and they seemed genuinely excited about becoming parents.

I knew that they would love and care for the baby, and that they would give him or her everything I couldn't.

It's still hard. It's still scary. I'm still grieving the loss of a future that will never be. But I know that I'm doing the right thing.

It's not about me. It's about the baby. And I want the best for him or her. Even if that means giving him or her up.

It's a complicated decision. And it's not one that I take lightly. But I'm at peace with it. And I'm hopeful for the future. For the baby, and for myself.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It just… makes it right. I think. I hope.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he just… overthinks things. And worries. A lot.

It's not that I don't understand his concern. He's my dad. He wants to protect me. And he's understandably protective about the baby, even though it's not his.

But he's acting like Mark and Vanessa are some kind of villains, trying to swindle me out of something. Which is just… ridiculous.

I've spent a lot of time with them. I've talked to them. I've gotten to know them. They're good people. They're kind and compassionate and they genuinely want to give this baby a loving home.

They're not trying to "rip me off." They're just trying to start a family. And they're willing to go through all the legal hoops and paperwork to make it happen.

I know Dad's worried about me regretting my decision. And he's worried about the baby being taken care of. But I've thought this through. A lot. And I'm confident that this is the right thing to do.

It's frustrating that he doesn't trust my judgment. It makes me feel like he doesn't think I'm capable of making my own decisions.

I've tried to explain it to him, but he just keeps bringing up worst-case scenarios. It's exhausting.

Bren's been really good about mediating. She's reminded him that I'm not a little kid anymore, and that I'm capable of making my own choices.

I love my dad, but sometimes he just needs to chill out. And trust that I know what I'm doing. I'm trying to be responsible and mature about this. And I wish he would just support me, instead of constantly questioning my decisions. It's my life, and I need to live it my way. Even if it's a messy, complicated way.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? He said that? Classic Mac.

It's… frustrating, okay? It's like he thinks I'm just being dramatic or attention-seeking or something. Like I'm not actually dealing with a lot of really complicated stuff.

He means well, I guess. He's just… not good at expressing his emotions. He's a man of few words, and he tends to shut down when things get difficult.

But it still stings. It makes me feel like he doesn't understand me. Like he doesn't see how much I'm struggling.

And it's not like I *want* to be going through this. I didn't ask for this. I didn't plan this. It just happened.

And I'm trying to handle it the best way I know how. I'm trying to be strong and independent and responsible. But it's hard. It's really hard.

So when he tells me I don't know when to say when, it feels like he's dismissing my feelings. Like he's telling me to just suck it up and deal with it.

But I can't just suck it up and deal with it. I need to talk about it. I need to process my emotions. I need to lean on my support system.

And I need my dad to be a part of that support system. Not to judge me or criticize me, but to listen to me and understand me.

It's just… ugh. He's my dad. I love him. But sometimes, he just doesn't get it. And it's really frustrating.

I probably won't say anything to him about it, though. It's not worth the argument. I'll just try to ignore it and focus on taking care of myself. And maybe eat a slice of pie. Pie always helps.

Ugh. Loring. Don't even get me started on Loring. It's… aggressively perfect. Like, Stepford Wives level perfect.

It's all manicured lawns and identical houses and people who look like they stepped out of a magazine. It's so… sterile. It feels like a movie set, not a real place.

And the gate? Seriously? A gate? Like they're trying to keep something *out*? Or keep something *in*? It's just… pretentious.

It's a symbol of everything I dislike about suburbia. The conformity, the materialism, the lack of authenticity.

Mark and Vanessa are really nice people, don't get me wrong. But living in Loring… it just feels so… disconnected from reality. Like they're living in a bubble.

I get that they want a safe and comfortable environment for the baby. But I also think it's important for the baby to be exposed to different kinds of people and different kinds of experiences.

Loring just feels… limiting. It feels like a place where creativity and individuality are stifled.

I'm glad Mark and Vanessa are happy there. But it's not a place where *I* would ever want to live. I need a little bit of grit and chaos in my life. I need a place where people are real, and where things aren't always perfect.

So yeah. Loring. It's nice, I guess. But it's not for me. It's just… too much. Too perfect. Too… Loring. It gives me the creeps, honestly.

Ugh, okay. Vanessa. Right. That's… a complicated one.

Honestly? My first impression was… she seemed *too* perfect. Like, Stepford Wife perfect. She was so… put together. Always smiling, always polite, always asking how *I* was doing. It felt a little bit fake, you know?

I was expecting someone… I don't know, more stern? More judgmental? Someone who would grill me about my life and my choices. But she was just… nice. Almost unnervingly nice.

I was suspicious. I thought she was trying to trick me. Like, she was putting on an act to make me feel comfortable.

Mark seemed more… real. He was a little bit awkward and clumsy, and he didn't try to hide his emotions. He was easier to read.

But Vanessa… she was a mystery. I couldn't figure her out.

I remember thinking she was really pretty, though. She had this really warm smile and kind eyes. And she smelled really good. Like vanilla and something else I couldn't quite place.

But I was still wary. I didn't want to get my hopes up. I didn't want to fall for a nice act.

It took me a while to realize that she wasn't being fake. She was just genuinely a kind and compassionate person. And that she really did want to give the baby a good home.

It took a few visits, a few conversations, to break down my walls and let her in. But eventually, I did. And I'm really glad I did. She's… a good person. A really good person. And I trust her with my baby. Even if she is a little bit too perfect sometimes. It's a good kind of perfect, I guess.

(Blushes slightly, even though you can't see it)

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive that. It was… awkward. And kinda sweet. And definitely confusing.

Bleeker is… Bleeker. He's quiet and awkward and kinda dorky. But he's also really nice. And he's a good listener.

So when he offered to carry my backpack, it was… unexpected. I mean, he barely even *talks* to me. And my backpack is, like, ridiculously heavy. It's full of textbooks and notebooks and a really bulky art portfolio.

I think I just stared at him for a minute, completely speechless. I was trying to figure out if he was joking or if he was serious.

And then I said something sarcastic, probably. I always say something sarcastic. It's my default setting.

But he just smiled and took the backpack. And he actually carried it for the rest of the walk to school.

It was… nice. It made me feel… seen. Like he noticed me. Like he cared.

I don't know what it meant. Maybe he was just being polite. Maybe he was trying to impress me. Maybe he just felt bad for me.

But it was a small gesture, and it made a big difference. It made me feel a little bit less alone.

And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, Bleeker wasn't as dorky as I thought he was.

(Looks away, fiddling with an imaginary strand of hair)

Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

(Sighs) Okay, you went there. You actually went there. Fine.

Look, it's complicated. It's not like reading that comic magically transformed me into a supermodel or something. I still felt… awkward. And self-conscious. And like I didn't quite fit in.

But it was the *way* Yuki felt. She was… unapologetically herself. She didn't care what other people thought. She was creative and quirky and a little bit weird. And she was okay with that.

And for some reason, that resonated with me. I realized that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be a little bit weird. It's okay to not conform to everyone else's expectations.

I'd been so focused on trying to be "normal," on trying to fit in, that I'd lost sight of who I was. I'd been hiding my true self, and it was making me miserable.

Yuki showed me that it's okay to embrace your flaws. It's okay to be yourself, even if that means being a "fat dork."

It wasn't about the comic itself, really. It was about the message. It was about finding someone who understood what it was like to feel like an outsider.

It didn't magically fix everything, but it gave me a little bit of hope. It gave me the courage to be a little bit more myself. And that's all I needed.

So yeah. That comic made me feel less like a fat dork. Not because it changed my appearance, but because it changed my perspective. And that's a pretty big deal. Don't judge. It's a good comic.

Ugh, don't remind me. That whole conversation was… awkward. But okay, I've thought about it a lot. And I think I have a pretty good idea.

Mark, he's a sweet guy, but he's also kinda clueless sometimes. He doesn't really *get* what's going on with me, I don't think. He just sees a pregnant teenager, and he tries to be supportive.

But when he compared me to that superhero in the comic… it wasn't about the pregnancy itself. It was about the fact that I'm still trying to be *me* despite everything.

That superhero, she was still fighting crime and saving the world, even though she was pregnant. She wasn't letting her pregnancy define her. She was still strong and independent and capable.

And I think Mark saw that in me. He saw that I was still going to school, still hanging out with my friends (well, sometimes), still pursuing my interests. I wasn't just sitting around feeling sorry for myself. I was trying to make the best of a bad situation.

He probably thought it was a nice, encouraging thing to say. And maybe it was. But it also felt… weird. Like he was trying to put me in a box. Like he was trying to define me by my pregnancy.

I'm not a superhero. I'm just a regular girl who made a mistake. And I'm trying to figure things out.

But I guess I can see his point. I am trying to be strong. I am trying to be independent. And I am trying to do the right thing. Even when it's hard.

So maybe, in a way, I *am* a superhero. Just a really flawed, sarcastic, and slightly cynical one. And definitely not wearing a cape.

Okay, this is… complicated. And it's something I've thought about a *lot*. Everyone keeps asking me about open adoption, like it's the best thing ever. But it's not necessarily the right thing for *everyone*.

Look, I get the appeal of open adoption. The idea of the baby being able to know their birth parents, of having a connection… it sounds nice. And I respect people who choose that route.

But for me, and for this situation, I think a traditional, closed adoption is better.

It's not about me not wanting to be involved in the baby's life. It's about wanting what's best for the baby. And I think what's best is a clean break. A chance for the baby to grow up in a stable, loving home without any confusion or complications.

I don't want to be a constant reminder of a difficult past. I don't want the baby to feel like they're being pulled in two different directions. I want them to have a clear sense of identity and belonging.

And honestly, it's also about me. I need to move on with my life. I need to heal and grow and build a future for myself. It would be too painful for me to have a constant reminder of what I gave up.

I know some people think that's selfish. But I don't think it is. I think it's about being realistic and honest about my own limitations.

I want Mark and Vanessa to be the baby's parents, fully and completely. I want them to have the freedom to raise the baby without any interference from me.

It's not easy. It's a difficult decision. But I truly believe it's the right one. It's the one that will give the baby the best chance at a happy and fulfilling life. And that's all that matters to me.

So yeah. I prefer a closed adoption. It's not about me wanting to forget the baby. It's about wanting to give them the best possible future. And sometimes, that means letting go. Completely.

(Sighs, a little softer than usual) Okay, wow. That's… a big question. It's not like there was a magical moment where everything clicked, you know? It was more like a slow burn. A lot of messy, uncomfortable growth.

Before everything happened, I was just… drifting. I was sarcastic and independent, yeah, but I didn't really *know* who I was. I was just trying to get through high school without being noticed too much. I was hiding behind my wit and my vintage clothes.

Then I got pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. I was forced to confront my own mortality, my own responsibility. I had to make a really difficult decision, and I had to own it.

And that's when I started to find my strength. It wasn't about being fearless. It was about being scared and doing it anyway. It was about admitting that I needed help, and accepting the support of the people who loved me.

Bren was a huge part of that. She didn't judge me. She didn't try to tell me what to do. She just listened, and she helped me to figure things out for myself.

And Mark and Vanessa… they showed me that there are good people in the world. People who are kind and compassionate and willing to open their hearts to others.

Through the whole process, I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I'm capable of making difficult decisions, and of living with the consequences. I learned that I'm not afraid to be vulnerable, and that vulnerability is actually a strength.

And I learned that my identity isn't defined by my circumstances. It's defined by my values, my beliefs, and my choices.

I'm still figuring things out, of course. I'm still a work in progress. But I'm more confident now. I'm more self-aware. And I'm more comfortable in my own skin.
