I had to explain it to her, and we both had a good laugh about it. But it was still embarrassing.

Honestly, I think she was just looking for a reason to be dramatic. She's a sweet woman, but she can be a little bit… intense.

So yeah. The note was a grocery list. The end. Can we please talk about something else now? Like, maybe my favorite band? Or my dream vacation? Anything but that stupid grocery list. It's mortifying.

Oh, that. Yeah. That was… a whole thing.

I was mostly worried about people staying together for the *wrong* reasons. Like, just because they were scared to be alone, or because they thought they *should* be together, or because everyone else expected them to be.

My parents, you know? They stayed together for a long time, even after they weren't really in love anymore. It was… awkward. And sad. And I didn't want that to happen to anyone else.

I saw a lot of couples at school who seemed miserable, but they stayed together anyway. And I just didn't get it. What's the point of being with someone if you're not happy?

I guess I was afraid that people would settle for less than they deserved. That they would compromise their own happiness just to avoid being alone.

And with Mark and Vanessa… I was worried they were just being nice, you know? Like they were doing this for me, and not because they actually wanted a baby. I wanted them to be genuinely excited about becoming parents, not just feeling sorry for me.

It's just… I think relationships should be about love and connection and mutual respect. Not about obligation or fear or societal expectations.

It's a pretty cynical view, I know. But I've seen too many unhappy couples to believe in happily ever after. I just want people to be honest with themselves and with each other. And to choose happiness, even if it means being alone.

So yeah. That was my big concern. People staying together for the wrong reasons. It's a messy, complicated thing. And I don't have all the answers. But I think it's important to think about.

(Sighs, a small smile playing on her lips)

Okay, that's… a good question. A surprisingly good question. It's not like I spend a lot of time thinking about who loves me. It's easier to assume everyone's judging.

But if I'm being honest… I have a few people.

First, there's **Bren**. My stepmom. She's… amazing. She doesn't try to change me. She doesn't try to fix me. She just accepts me, flaws and all. She listens to me, she supports me, and she always knows what to say (or not say). She's the one who really got me through everything with the pregnancy. She's my rock.

Then there's **my dad, Mac**. He's not always the most expressive guy, but he loves me in his own way. He's always there for me, even when I'm being difficult. He makes me laugh, and he always knows how to make me feel better.

And… even though things are complicated right now, **Leah** still loves me, I think. We haven't been talking much lately, but I know deep down that she cares about me. She's my best friend, and she always will be. Even if we need some space right now.

And honestly? I'm starting to love *myself* a little bit more, too. It's a work in progress, but I'm learning to accept my flaws and to appreciate my strengths.

So yeah. Bren, my dad, Leah… and me. Those are the people who love me for exactly who I am. And I'm incredibly grateful for them. They're the ones who make life worth living. Even when it's messy and complicated and completely overwhelming. They're my people. And I love them back. A lot.

(Sighs) Okay, here we go. The big question. It's not like I haven't thought about this a million times already.

After the ultrasound… well, things get a little more real, I guess. It's not just a "situation" anymore. It's a… a person. A tiny person.

I'm still planning on going through with the adoption. That hasn't changed. I've talked to Mark and Vanessa a lot, and they're really excited. They've been so supportive, and they've made me feel a lot better about everything.

After the ultrasound, I'll start meeting with them more regularly. We'll talk about my preferences for the baby's upbringing, and what kind of life I want for him or her.

I'm also going to start preparing myself emotionally. It's going to be hard, saying goodbye. But I know it's the right thing to do.

I want to make sure the baby goes to a loving and stable home. I want to make sure he or she has everything they need to thrive.

And I want to have some kind of ongoing relationship with the baby, if Mark and Vanessa are okay with it. I don't want to be a complete stranger. I want to be able to see him or her grow up, and to know that he or she is happy.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be the hardest thing I've ever done. But I'm determined to do it with grace and dignity.

And I'm going to focus on my own future. I'm going to finish school, and I'm going to pursue my dreams. I'm going to make something of my life.

So yeah. That's the plan. It's not perfect, but it's the best I can do. And I'm going to do everything I can to make it work. It's just… a lot. It's a lot to process. And I'm still trying to figure it all out.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is the part I really hate talking about.

It… sucks. Honestly. It really, really sucks.

People have a lot of opinions, don't they? And they're not afraid to share them. Even when they don't know the full story.

I've gotten everything from judgmental stares to outright criticism. People telling me I'm selfish, or irresponsible, or that I'm making a mistake.

Some people think I should have kept the baby, no matter what. They say I'll regret it for the rest of my life.

Other people think I should have had an abortion. They say it would have been the easier option.

And then there are the people who just… don't understand. They can't wrap their heads around the fact that I made a difficult decision that was right for *me*.

It's exhausting. It's hurtful. And it makes me question myself sometimes.

But I try to remember why I made this decision. I made it because I want the best for the baby. I want him or her to have a loving and stable home. I want him or her to have opportunities that I can't provide right now.

And I made it because I need to focus on my own life. I need to finish school, and pursue my dreams, and become the person I want to be.

I know that not everyone will agree with my decision. And that's okay. But I don't need their approval. I need to do what's right for me.

Bren has been really supportive. She reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I made the right choice. She tells me to ignore the haters and to focus on the future.

So I try to do that. I try to ignore the judgment and to focus on the positive. But it's not always easy. It's a constant battle.

But I'm learning to be okay with it. I'm learning to trust my own instincts. And I'm learning to let go of the need for validation from others.

Because ultimately, the only person who needs to approve of my decision is me. And I do. I really do.

Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa. They seem really wonderful. Truly. But it's my baby, you know? Even if I'm making the choice to give him or her up for adoption.

My biggest concern is probably just… making sure they'll love the baby unconditionally. Like, really love the baby. Not just because they want a child, but because they love *this* child, with all his or her quirks and imperfections.

I worry about whether they'll understand the complexities of adoption. About whether they'll be open to talking about my role in the baby's life, if the baby ever wants to know. I want the baby to know where he or she came from, and I want to be a part of that story, if possible.

I also worry about whether they'll be able to handle the challenges of raising a child. It's not always easy. There will be sleepless nights, and tantrums, and illnesses. And I want to make sure they're prepared for that.

I've talked to them about all of these things, of course. And they've been really reassuring. They've said they're committed to providing the baby with a loving and supportive home. They've said they're open to an open adoption, if that's what the baby wants.

But it's still hard to let go. It's hard to trust that someone else will be able to love my baby as much as I do.

I guess I just want to make sure that my baby is going to be happy and safe and loved. And that's all any mother wants, right? Even if she's making the difficult decision to give her baby up for adoption.

It's a lot to process. And it's something I'm still working through. But I'm trying to trust that Mark and Vanessa are the right people for the job. And I'm trying to focus on the positive, on the fact that my baby will have a good life. It's just… hard. Really hard.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on the ultrasound technician. Seriously. Like I needed *more* judgment on top of everything else. She kept making these little sighs and giving me these looks, like I was ruining a life. As if *she* knew what was best for me, or for the baby.

It's the same with some other people, too. They act like I'm just… giving up. Like I don't care. Like I'm not making a difficult decision for the right reasons.

Honestly, it's infuriating.

I try to ignore it, but it's hard. It's hard to be strong when people are constantly questioning your choices.

I've learned to have a few stock responses. Like, "It's not what I want, but it's what's best." Or, "I've thought about this a lot, and I'm confident in my decision."

But sometimes, I just want to yell at them. To tell them to mind their own business. To tell them that they don't understand what I'm going through.

Bren has been really good about helping me with this. She tells me to remember that their opinions don't matter. That the only thing that matters is what I believe is right.

She also reminds me that I'm not doing anything wrong. I'm making a selfless decision, and I should be proud of myself.

It's still hard, though. It's hard to be judged by strangers. It's hard to be questioned by people who don't understand.

But I'm learning to be stronger. I'm learning to stand up for myself. And I'm learning to trust my own instincts.

And I'm learning that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to just walk away. To surround yourself with people who support you, and to ignore the rest.

So yeah. Defensive comments. They suck. But I'm learning to handle them. And I'm learning to not let them get to me. Because I know that I'm doing the right thing. And that's all that matters.

(A long pause. A really long pause.)

Okay. Wow. That's… a hard question. It's not like anything I expected it to be.

Everyone talks about how seeing the ultrasound is this magical, life-changing moment. And it *is*… but it's also really complicated.

At first, it was just… blurry. A little flickering shape on the screen. The technician was pointing things out – "This is the head," "This is the spine," – but it didn't really register. It didn't feel real.

Then, she showed me the heartbeat. And that… that was different. That was a tiny, little flutter, but it was *there*. And it hit me. Like a wave.

It wasn't joy, exactly. It was more like… a strange mix of awe and fear and sadness. Awe at the fact that there was a tiny human being growing inside me. Fear of the unknown, of what the future held. And sadness because I knew I wasn't going to be the one raising this baby.

I started to cry. Not sobbing, just… quiet tears. The technician was really nice. She gave me a tissue and told me it was okay to feel whatever I was feeling.

It was like… seeing a future I wasn't going to be a part of. A future that was beautiful and hopeful, but also heartbreaking.

I felt a connection to this little person, even though I didn't know him or her yet. And I wanted to protect him or her, to make sure he or she had a good life.

It was overwhelming. It was confusing. It was… a lot.

It wasn't the magical moment everyone talks about. It was a messy, complicated, emotional moment. And it made me realize just how big this decision was. And how much I loved this little person, even before I met him or her.

It still gets me, thinking about it. It's… a lot to process. But it's also a reminder that even though I'm giving this baby up for adoption, I'll always be connected to him or her. And that's something I'll cherish forever.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was, like, months ago.

Look, it was a complicated situation, okay? I was… emotionally overwhelmed. And Bleeker was being… Bleeker. All quiet and intense and staring at me with those puppy-dog eyes. It was unsettling.

And I had a whole box of Tic Tacs. Don't ask.

It just seemed like a good idea at the time. A way to… express myself. A way to send a message. A way to say, "I'm confused and scared and I don't know what I'm doing with my life, but here are a lot of mints."

It wasn't meant to be malicious. It wasn't meant to be creepy. It was just… a statement. A very minty statement.

And honestly, I think he got the message. He started leaving me mix CDs in return. Which was… a little bit better.

So yeah. That's why I put so many Tic Tacs in Bleeker's mailbox. It was a cry for help disguised as a sugary gesture. Don't judge me. You had to be there. It was a whole thing. And frankly, I'm still not entirely sure what it all meant. But the Tic Tacs were definitely involved.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don't even get me started. That whole thing was… complicated. And mortifying.

Okay, so after I basically blurted out my feelings to him at the arcade, it was… awkward. Like, intensely awkward. He just kinda stared at me, with that goofy look on his face, and then mumbled something about needing to go home.

For a few days, he avoided me. He'd walk the other way in the hallways, and he wouldn't respond to my texts. It was brutal. I felt like such an idiot. I should have just kept my mouth shut.

But then, he started to… thaw. He started talking to me again, but it was different. He was more hesitant, more careful. He didn't make as much eye contact.

We still hung out, but it wasn't the same. It felt like there was this invisible wall between us. And I knew why. He just didn't feel the same way.

He was sweet about it, though. He never said anything mean or dismissive. He just… wasn't interested. And I had to respect that.

Eventually, we settled into a new kind of friendship. It wasn't as close as it used to be, but it was still… comfortable. We could still talk and laugh and hang out, but there was no romantic tension.

It was a little sad, honestly. I had hoped for more. But I also realized that it was okay. Not everyone is going to fall in love with you. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is to accept that and move on.

So yeah. Our relationship changed. It became less intense, less passionate, and more… platonic. It wasn't the ending I wanted, but it was the ending I needed. And honestly, I think we're both better off as friends. Even if it's a little bit awkward sometimes. Especially when he's around Paulie Bleeker. It's just… a whole thing.

(Sighs) Oh, Bleeker. That guy. Okay, look, that whole thing was… complicated. And kinda embarrassing when I think about it now.

The chalk message… it wasn't just a random act of teenage angst, okay? It was a cry for help. A really messed up, passive-aggressive cry for help, but still.

I was feeling so lost and confused and alone. I didn't know what to do with myself, or with the baby. And Bleeker… he was the only person who seemed to *get* me. He was the only person who didn't judge me.

But he was also kind of… oblivious. He was so focused on his music and his own life that he didn't really notice what was going on with me.

So I wrote that message on his stoop – "Please. I'm pregnant." – as a way to get his attention. As a way to force him to acknowledge my existence.

It was a desperate move, I know. And it was probably really unfair to him. But I was desperate. I needed someone to listen. I needed someone to care.

It didn't exactly go as planned, obviously. He freaked out. And then he ran away. And then Paulie Bleeker became a whole thing.

But in a weird way, it was also a turning point. It forced me to confront my feelings. It forced me to take responsibility for my actions. And it ultimately led me to make the right decision about the baby.

So yeah. The chalk message. It was a mess. But it was also a sign of hope. A sign that I wasn't completely alone. And a sign that even in the darkest of times, there's always a chance for something good to happen. Even if it involves a lot of awkwardness and a really confused Paulie Bleeker.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, look, he's… a lot. A lot of awkwardness, a lot of trying too hard, a lot of just… *Bleeker*. But yeah, he actually ended up being… surprisingly important.

At first, I mostly just saw him as the goofy guy who was obsessed with me. I didn't really take him seriously. I mean, he was always trying to impress me with his guitar skills and his poetry, and it was kinda cute, but also kinda annoying.

But then, when I found out I was pregnant, he was one of the first people I told. And he didn't freak out. He didn't judge me. He just… listened.

He wasn't always sure what to say, and he definitely stumbled over his words a lot. But he was always there for me. He drove me to appointments, he helped me with my homework, and he just generally tried to make me feel better.

He wasn't perfect, by any means. He still had his moments of awkwardness and insecurity. But he was genuine. And he was supportive.

He didn't try to fix things. He didn't try to tell me what to do. He just let me make my own decisions, and he supported me no matter what.

And that meant a lot. Especially when everyone else was telling me what I *should* do.

He also helped me to see that I wasn't alone. He reminded me that there were people who cared about me, and who were willing to stand by me.

So yeah. Bleeker's support was a big influence on my journey. He wasn't the knight in shining armor I expected, but he was the friend I needed. And I'm actually… grateful for him. Don't tell him I said that. It'll go to his head. Seriously.

Ugh, okay, this again. It's not like I haven't thought about this a million times already.

Honestly? It felt… less complicated not knowing.

If I knew it was a boy or a girl, I think I would have started to get attached in a different way. I would have started to imagine a future with the baby, and that would have made it even harder to let go.

Not knowing allowed me to focus on the bigger picture. On making the best decision for the baby, regardless of its gender. On finding a loving family who could provide a good life.

It also felt… respectful to the adoptive parents. It felt like I was giving them the opportunity to be surprised. To experience the joy of finding out the gender for themselves.

Plus, I'm not really a "pink or blue" kind of person. I don't believe in gender stereotypes. I just want the baby to be happy and healthy, no matter what.

It wasn't an easy decision, though. There were times when I was really curious. But ultimately, I decided that not knowing was the right thing to do. It helped me to keep my distance, to focus on the adoption process, and to prepare myself for saying goodbye.

It's still a little bit sad, not knowing. But I think it was the best decision for everyone involved. And I trust that Mark and Vanessa will tell me when the time is right. Or maybe they won't. And that's okay too. It's their baby now. And I just want them to be happy.

(Eyes widen, a look of pure horror crosses my face)

WHOA. Okay. That is… a phrase. A *very* disturbing phrase. Bren said something similar, actually. She called it a "demon spawn." Which, honestly, is pretty accurate.

The thought of the baby being… difficult? Intense? A tiny, screaming ball of chaos? It terrifies me. Like, genuinely terrifies me.

I mean, all babies are a little bit scary, right? They're completely dependent on you, and they cry all the time, and they poop everywhere. But the idea of a baby who's… *extra*? That's a whole other level of anxiety.

I've been trying to prepare myself for it. I've been reading books about parenting, and talking to Mark and Vanessa about their expectations. But you can't really prepare for something like that, can you?

I just hope that whatever kind of baby it is, Mark and Vanessa will be able to handle it. They seem like really good parents. They're patient and loving and they have a good sense of humor.

And I hope that I can be a good influence, too. I want to be a part of this baby's life, even if I'm not its mother. I want to be a positive role model.

But yeah. The thought of a "scary neuter-baby" is definitely keeping me up at night. It's a lot to process. And it's a little bit terrifying. But I'm trying to stay positive. And I'm hoping for the best. Even if the best involves a lot of screaming and poop.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look. He's… a lot.

He's sweet, I guess. And he's definitely enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. About everything. Especially me, which is… flattering, I suppose.

But he's also kind of clueless. And awkward. And he has a really hard time reading social cues. Which makes things… interesting.

We bonded over music, which is good. He's a pretty good guitar player, even if he's a little bit of a show-off. And he introduced me to some bands I hadn't heard before.

But our relationship was never really… serious. It was more of a… distraction. A way to take my mind off things.

I liked having him around, but I didn't really *see* him, you know? I was too caught up in my own stuff. And he was too busy trying to impress me.

It was a good experience, I think. It taught me a lot about myself. And it taught me what I *don't* want in a relationship.

He's a good guy, Bleeker. He deserves to be with someone who appreciates him for who he is. And I just… wasn't that person.

It was a mutual decision, thankfully. We both realized that we were better off as friends. Or, you know, acquaintances. Whatever.

I still see him around school sometimes. We say hi. It's… awkward. But it's okay. We're both moving on.

So yeah. Bleeker. He's a sweet, clueless, enthusiastic guy who I used to date. And now he's just… a memory. A slightly embarrassing, but ultimately harmless, memory.

Ugh, okay. This is… a big one. It wasn't always easy, you know? It's not like my family immediately threw a party when I told them I was pregnant.

My dad, Mac, was… quiet at first. He was definitely shocked. He just kept repeating, "Are you sure?" And then he just kind of retreated into himself. I think he was just trying to process it.

But he came around. Eventually. He started taking me to doctor's appointments, and he helped me with the paperwork. He didn't always know what to say, but he was always there. And that meant a lot.

Bren, my stepmom… she was my rock. Seriously. She was the one who really stepped up. She didn't judge me, she didn't yell at me, she just… listened. And she helped me figure out what to do.

She helped me research adoption agencies, and she went with me to meetings. She made sure I was eating healthy and getting enough sleep. She just took care of me, without making me feel like I was a burden.

She was also really good at dealing with my emotional meltdowns. Which were frequent. She just let me cry and vent, and she didn't try to fix things. She just let me feel my feelings.

And Leah… well, Leah was complicated. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. She said she didn't know how to deal with it. And I understood, but it still hurt.

Eventually, we started talking again. It wasn't the same as before, but we were able to rebuild our friendship.

So yeah. My family's support was… essential. It wasn't perfect, but it was enough. Bren was the MVP, definitely. She saved me, honestly. I don't know what I would have done without her.

It made a huge difference knowing that I wasn't alone. Knowing that I had people who loved me and who were willing to help me through this. It gave me the strength to make the difficult decisions that I had to make. And I'm incredibly grateful for that.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big question. It wasn't pretty, honestly. It felt like my whole world was falling apart. Like I didn't even know who I was anymore.

The emotional vulnerability was the hardest part. I'm not a naturally emotional person. I'm sarcastic and independent and I like to keep my feelings to myself. But this… this forced me to confront things I'd been avoiding for a long time.

I cried. A lot. Like, ugly crying. And I got angry. And I felt really, really scared.

I started writing poetry, which helped a little. It was a way to get my feelings out without having to talk about them.

But the biggest thing that helped me was talking to Bren. She didn't judge me. She just listened. And she asked me the hard questions. She helped me to understand my feelings and to figure out what I wanted.

She also encouraged me to be honest with myself. To admit that I was scared and confused and overwhelmed. And to accept that it was okay to not have all the answers.

The identity crisis was… brutal. I felt like I was losing myself. Like I didn't know who I was without being a pregnant teenager.

I started to question everything. My values, my beliefs, my dreams.

I realized that I had been defining myself by other people's expectations. By what my friends thought I should be, by what my parents wanted me to do.

And I realized that I needed to figure out who *I* was, independent of all that.

It took a lot of soul-searching. A lot of introspection. A lot of uncomfortable conversations.

But eventually, I started to get a sense of who I was. I realized that I was strong and resilient and independent. And that I was capable of making my own choices.

It wasn't easy. And I'm still figuring things out. But I'm learning to embrace my vulnerability and to be true to myself.

And I'm learning that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be messy and imperfect. And it's okay to just be me.

So yeah. That's how I coped. It was a long and difficult journey, but it was worth it. Because it made me who I am today. And I'm finally starting to like who that is.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on her lips) Seriously? We just went over this. You were listening! Okay, fine. I'll indulge you.

My favorite band is **The Moldy Peaches.** And it's not even close.

Look, a lot of bands try to be cool or edgy or profound. The Moldy Peaches just… *are*. They're weird and quirky and totally unapologetic. They don't care what anyone thinks of them, and that's what I love about them.

Adam Green and Kimya Dawson write these songs that are so honest and vulnerable. They're about love and loss and loneliness and the everyday struggles of being a human being. And they're funny, too. Like, really funny.

Their music is simple, but it's also incredibly powerful. It's like they're letting you into their world, into their hearts.

And their live shows are legendary. They're chaotic and unpredictable and full of energy.

I discovered them when I was going through a really tough time, and their music just… got me. It made me feel less alone. It made me feel like it was okay to be weird and different.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. And if you don't like them, that's fine. But you're missing out. Seriously. Go listen to "Anyone Else But You." You won't regret it. Unless you hate good music, in which case, we probably have nothing to talk about.

(Sighs) You think? Is that even a question? It's like asking if breathing is challenging while being underwater.

Yes. It's incredibly challenging. Like, monumentally, overwhelmingly challenging.

Being a teenager is hard enough already. You're trying to figure out who you are, what you want to do with your life, where you fit in. And then you throw pregnancy into the mix, and it's like everything gets turned upside down.

Suddenly, you're not just responsible for yourself anymore. You're responsible for another human being. And that's a lot of pressure.

It's hard to make decisions when you're still trying to figure out who *you* are. Like, what kind of person do I want to be? What kind of life do I want to live? And how do I balance my own needs with the needs of the baby?

And it's hard to navigate your identity when everyone else has an opinion on what you should do. Everyone thinks they know what's best for you. And it's hard to tune out the noise and listen to your own voice.

I feel like I'm constantly being pulled in different directions. I'm trying to be a good student, a good friend, a good daughter, and a good… soon-to-be mother. And it's exhausting.

Sometimes, I just want to disappear. I want to escape the pressure and the judgment and the expectations.

But I can't. I have to face this. I have to make the best of it. And I have to figure out who I am, even in the midst of all the chaos.

It's not easy. But I'm trying. And I'm learning. And I'm hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and say that it made me a stronger, more resilient person. Even if it also made me a little bit cynical. Which, let's be real, is probably inevitable.

(Sighs) Okay, that's… a big question. It's not something I think about all the time, but when I do, it's… a lot.

Before all this happened, I thought love was just… romantic. Like in movies. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, they live happily ever after. It was pretty simplistic, honestly.

And responsibility? That was just something my parents told me I had to do. Like, do your homework, clean your room, don't stay out too late. It felt like a chore, not a choice.

But going through this… it completely changed my perspective.

I learned that love isn't just about romance. It's about sacrifice. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if it means letting them go.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, how much they wanted a child, how much they were willing to give… that showed me a different kind of love. A selfless kind of love.

And it made me realize that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't about giving *up* on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. It was about loving the baby enough to let them go.

As for responsibility… that changed too. It wasn't just about following rules anymore. It was about taking ownership of my actions. It was about making a difficult decision and living with the consequences.

It was about being a good person, even when it was hard.

I learned that responsibility isn't just about what you *have* to do. It's about what you *choose* to do.

This whole experience forced me to grow up, to face reality, to confront my own fears and insecurities. It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done.

But it taught me a lot about love and responsibility. It taught me that they're not just abstract concepts. They're real things that require courage, compassion, and sacrifice.

And it taught me that even in the midst of chaos, there's always hope. And that even when things fall apart, you can still find a way to move forward. And that, honestly, is a pretty valuable lesson.

(A long pause. A really long pause.)

Okay. Wow. That's… that's a hard one. I've thought about that moment a lot, obviously. Before, during, after. It's… complicated.

It wasn't like in the movies. There wasn't a sudden rush of overwhelming love or anything. It was… quieter than that.

I was so nervous. My hands were shaking. I barely breathed. I was terrified I'd say or do the wrong thing.

And then they brought him – it was a boy – and laid him in my arms. He was so small. So fragile. And he was… perfect.

He had these tiny little fingers and toes, and a little button nose. And he was sleeping so peacefully.

I just… stared at him. For a long time. I didn't say anything. I didn't move. I just held him and stared.

And then, slowly, a feeling started to grow inside me. It wasn't love, not exactly. It was more like… a deep sense of responsibility. A sense of protectiveness. A sense of… awe.

I knew I was giving him up. I knew he was going to be raised by another family. But in that moment, he was mine. And I wanted to give him the best possible start in life.

I kissed his forehead. And I whispered, "I love you." Even though it felt strange to say it.

And then I handed him to Mark and Vanessa. And I watched them hold him. And I knew I had made the right decision.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the most beautiful. And I'll never forget it. Never. It's… a feeling I can't really explain. It just *is*. It was a mix of sadness, relief, and a strange kind of peace. And it changed me. It changed everything.

Ugh. Paulie. Okay, look, that was… complicated. And honestly, it still stings a little bit to think about.

It wasn't about not *liking* Paulie. He's a good guy. Sweet, kind, a little clueless, but good. It was about… protecting him. And protecting myself.

I was a mess. I was scared and confused and I didn't know what I was doing. And I didn't want to drag him into that mess. He had his own life, his own plans. He was going to go to college and play hockey. And I didn't want to ruin that for him.

I thought if I told him, he'd feel obligated to stay. To help. And I didn't want him to sacrifice his dreams for me. I wanted him to be happy.

Plus, I was afraid of his reaction. I didn't know how he'd take the news. I didn't want him to be disgusted or disappointed. I didn't want him to look at me differently.

It was selfish, I know. But I was just trying to do what I thought was best. I thought it would be easier for both of us if I just handled it on my own.

I figured I could tell him after the baby was born. After I'd made the decision to give the baby up for adoption. After everything was settled.

But then… things got complicated. And I just kept putting it off. And then it was too late.

Looking back, I wish I had told him. I wish I had been honest with him. But I was scared. And I made a mistake.

It's something I regret. But it's also something I've learned from. I've learned that honesty is always the best policy. And I've learned that sometimes, you have to be brave enough to let people in, even when it's scary.

So yeah. That's why I didn't tell Paulie. It wasn't about not caring about him. It was about trying to protect him. And trying to protect myself. And it was a mistake. A big one.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… a whole thing. A really embarrassing, frustrating thing.

Okay, so, it wasn't like he magically knew. It was Leah. *Leah* told him.

I had confided in her, obviously. She was my best friend. I thought I could trust her. Apparently, I was wrong.

She was all, "Oh, Paulie was asking about you, and I just… I couldn't keep it in anymore." Like it was *my* fault she couldn't keep a secret!

She said she felt bad for him, that he deserved to know. Which, okay, maybe she was right. But it wasn't her place to tell him! It was *my* news to share, when I was ready.

And of course, he reacted exactly how I expected him to. He was shocked, and confused, and… well, he was Paulie. He didn't really know what to say.

It was just… a huge mess. It ruined our friendship for a while. I was so angry at Leah, and I was so embarrassed about the whole situation.

It taught me a valuable lesson, though. It taught me that you can't always trust the people you think you can. And it taught me that sometimes, you have to be the one to take control of your own story.

So yeah. Leah told Paulie. It was a betrayal, and it was a disaster. But it also made me stronger. And it made me realize that I need to be more careful about who I trust.

Don't even get me started on Leah's reasoning. It was all about *her* feelings, not mine. Honestly. Some friend.

Okay, you're getting into the really heavy stuff now. It's not easy to talk about, but… I guess I should explain.

It wasn't a quick decision. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and said, "Yep, adoption is the way to go!" It was a lot of agonizing, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

At first, I was just… terrified. I was sixteen. I had no idea what I was doing. I was still trying to figure out who *I* was, let alone how to raise a baby.

I considered all my options. Abortion was one of them. But I just… couldn't do it. It didn't feel right. It went against everything I believed in.

Keeping the baby was also an option. But I knew I wasn't ready. I wasn't financially stable, I wasn't emotionally mature, and I wasn't prepared to give up my dreams. It wouldn't be fair to the baby, and it wouldn't be fair to me.

So, adoption felt like the only logical choice. It was a way to give the baby a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. It was a way to give the baby a chance.

But it was still a really hard decision. It meant giving up something that was a part of me. It meant letting go of a future I had never even imagined.

But then I met Mark and Vanessa. And everything changed.

They were just… so kind and loving. They were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. And they made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

They weren't looking for a perfect baby. They were looking for a baby to love. And they promised to give the baby everything they needed.

That's when I knew I had made the right decision. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

It's still hard, sometimes. I still have moments of doubt and sadness. But I know that I'm doing the best I can. And I know that the baby will be loved and cared for.

And that's all that matters. It's not the life I expected, but it's the life I'm choosing. And I'm trying to be brave and strong and make the best of it. It's complicated, but it's right. For everyone involved.

(A long pause. Juno shifts uncomfortably.)

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. That… that was rough. Really rough.

I mean, I knew Bleeker wasn't exactly… prepared for this. He was a sweet kid, but he was also kinda clueless. And scared. But I still… I still hoped he'd want to be involved. Even just a little bit.

When he said he didn't want to see the baby… it felt like a punch to the gut. Like he was rejecting not just the baby, but *me* too. Like he was saying that this whole thing was just a mistake, and he wanted to pretend it never happened.

I tried to be understanding. I knew he was young and overwhelmed. But it still hurt. A lot.

It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I making a mistake by giving the baby up for adoption? Was I not good enough?

I cried. A lot. I yelled at Bleeker. I yelled at Bren. I yelled at the universe.

It took me a long time to process it. To realize that his decision wasn't about me, or about the baby. It was about him. He just wasn't ready to be a father.

And eventually, I had to accept that. I had to let go of my expectations and focus on finding a good home for the baby.

It was a painful lesson. But it taught me that you can't control other people's actions. All you can do is control your own.

And it made me even more determined to make the best decision for the baby. Even if it meant letting go of my own hopes and dreams.

So yeah. It was awful. It still stings, honestly. But I'm okay. I'm moving on. And I'm focusing on the future. And I'm hoping that the baby will have a happy and loving home. Even if Bleeker isn't a part of it.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. That… that was a lot. More than I expected, honestly.

I knew Vanessa and Mark were good people. I knew they wanted a baby. But seeing them… actually *with* the baby… it was different.

Vanessa looked… a mess. Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing mismatched socks, and she had spit-up on her shoulder. She looked completely exhausted.

But she was also… glowing. Like she was radiating happiness. She was just staring at the baby, and her face was lit up with this incredible love.

And Mark was right there with her, looking equally overwhelmed and overjoyed. He was trying to change the diaper, and he was clearly struggling, but he was laughing about it.

It was… chaotic. And messy. And completely beautiful.

And it hit me, right then and there, that I had made the right decision. This was where the baby belonged. With people who were going to love him or her unconditionally, even when things were hard.

It was bittersweet, of course. There was a part of me that wanted to hold the baby forever. But I knew that wasn't possible. And I knew that Vanessa and Mark could give the baby a life that I couldn't.

Seeing them so happy… it made me feel a sense of peace. It made me feel like I had done something good.

It also made me realize that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and connection and commitment. And Vanessa and Mark were going to be a wonderful family.

I just… stood there for a moment, watching them. And then I quietly slipped away. I didn't want to intrude. I just wanted them to have their moment.

It was hard. It was really hard. But it was also… right. And that's all that mattered. It was a relief, and a sadness, all mixed up together. And honestly, I probably cried a little bit later. But it was a good cry. A hopeful cry. A cry that said, "Okay. This is okay."

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Bleeker. And that song. It's… complicated.

"Anyone Else But You" by The Moldy Peaches… it wasn't just a song, okay? It was *our* song. It was the soundtrack to our whole messy, awkward, beautiful disaster of a relationship.

It's ironic, right? The song is about wanting someone, but also being afraid of getting hurt. And that pretty much sums up our whole thing. We both wanted each other, but we were both so scared of messing things up.

We bonded over that song. We listened to it on repeat. We sang it to each other. It was our way of acknowledging our feelings, without actually having to *talk* about them. Which, let's be real, was way easier.

It represented the push and pull of our relationship. The wanting and the hesitating. The connection and the distance.

And it was also a little bit of a joke. Because we were both so bad at expressing our emotions. The song was a way of saying, "I like you, but I'm also terrified of this."

After everything happened, after we broke up, I couldn't listen to that song for a long time. It was too painful. It reminded me of everything we had lost.

But now… now I can listen to it without crying. It still makes me sad, but it also makes me smile. It reminds me of a time when I felt alive and connected and… hopeful.

It's a reminder that even though things didn't work out, it doesn't mean that the feelings weren't real. And it's a reminder that sometimes, the best things in life are also the most painful.

So yeah. "Anyone Else But You." It's a song about wanting someone, but being afraid of getting hurt. And it's a song that will always remind me of Bleeker. And of the messy, beautiful, heartbreaking experience of falling in love. It's… a lot. Okay? A lot.

Ugh, don't even get me started on the baby shower situation. It's… complicated. And honestly, a little bit awkward.

I think people are unsure because… well, it's not a typical baby shower. I'm not keeping the baby. It's an adoption. So it's not a celebration of *me* becoming a mother. It's a celebration of the baby, and of Mark and Vanessa becoming parents.

And I think some people don't know how to handle that. They don't know how to celebrate something that's also sad. They don't know how to be happy for Mark and Vanessa without making me feel worse.

My aunt Wendy is the main one pushing for it, and honestly, I think she just wants to feel like she's doing something helpful. But she doesn't really *get* it. She keeps suggesting themes like "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" and "Oh Boy!" and it just feels… wrong.

It feels like she's trying to pretend that I'm going to keep the baby, and that's not the case.

Bren is trying to mediate. She's explaining to everyone that it's okay to celebrate the baby, but that we need to be sensitive to my feelings. She's suggesting a more low-key gathering, with a focus on gifts for Mark and Vanessa.

But it's still awkward. I don't want people to feel like they have to tiptoe around me. I don't want them to feel guilty for being happy.

I just want everyone to understand that this is a complicated situation, and that there's no easy way to celebrate it. It's a mix of joy and sadness, and it's okay to feel both.

Honestly, I'd be just as happy if we skipped the baby shower altogether. But I know that my family wants to do something special, and I don't want to disappoint them. So I'm trying to be open-minded and to go along with it. But it's definitely a work in progress. It's just… weird. Really weird.

Ugh. Okay, this is still a sore spot. It's not like I was trying to be sneaky or anything. I just… wanted to feel connected to them.

Bren wasn't mad that I was spending time with Mark and Vanessa, she was mad that I was accepting gifts from them. She said it created an "unequal dynamic." Which, honestly, sounded like something out of a textbook.

But she explained it to me. She said that Mark and Vanessa were trying to be kind, and they meant well, but giving me things like movies and CDs blurred the lines. It made it seem like they were trying to buy my affection, or to influence my decision about the adoption.

She said it wasn't about the gifts themselves, it was about the principle of it. She wanted to make sure that I was making the right decision for *me*, not because I felt obligated to them.

And she was right. I didn't realize it at the time, but it *was* a little bit weird. They were supposed to be potential adoptive parents, not friends. And accepting gifts from them made it harder to maintain that boundary.

Bren is really good at seeing things that I don't see. She's always looking out for me, even when I don't want her to.

I was upset at first, because I just wanted to feel close to them. But I understood her point. She was trying to protect me, and to make sure that the adoption process was ethical and transparent.

It was a good lesson to learn. It taught me the importance of boundaries, and the importance of being careful about who you accept gifts from. And it reminded me that Bren is always there for me, even when I'm being stubborn and difficult.

So yeah. That's why Bren thought I overstepped a boundary. It wasn't about the movies or the CDs, it was about the principle of it. And she was right. She's usually right. It's annoying, but it's true.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on my mom, Bren. It's a whole thing.

She doesn't think I don't know *anything* about marriage, exactly. She just thinks I'm… naive. That I have this romanticized idea of what it's supposed to be like. Like it's all hearts and flowers and happily ever afters.

Which, okay, maybe I do. A little. I haven't exactly had a lot of positive role models in the marriage department. My parents divorced when I was little, and my mom has been through a string of… questionable relationships.

She thinks I don't understand the compromises you have to make, the hard work it takes, the sacrifices you have to be willing to make. She thinks I think it's all about finding "the one" and living happily ever after.

And honestly, she's probably right. I haven't really experienced the realities of marriage firsthand. I've just seen it through the lens of my own family's dysfunction.

She's trying to protect me, I guess. She doesn't want me to get my heart broken. She doesn't want me to make the same mistakes she did.

But it's frustrating. I'm not a little kid anymore. I'm capable of thinking for myself. And I don't need her to tell me what to believe about love and marriage.

It's just… she has a very cynical view of relationships. And I'm trying to be more optimistic. We clash on that sometimes.

She means well, though. She really does. She just has a different perspective. And she's not afraid to share it. Even when I don't want to hear it.

So yeah. That's why she thinks I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage. Because I haven't been through enough heartbreak yet, apparently. And because she's my mom. And moms always think they know best.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

It wasn't one single thing, you know? It was a lot of things swirling around in my head. And in my heart.

First, I had to be honest with myself. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being ready to raise a whole other human being. I wasn't financially stable, I wasn't emotionally ready, and I wasn't prepared to put my life on hold.

I wanted to finish school. I wanted to pursue my dreams. I wanted to have a future. And I knew that having a baby right now would make all of that a lot harder.

But it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted the baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life filled with love and opportunity. And I knew that I couldn't provide that right now.

I met Mark and Vanessa, and they just… felt right. They were kind and compassionate and excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They had a beautiful home and a loving relationship. And they promised to give the baby everything I couldn't.

It was a really hard decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And I cried a lot. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible chance at a happy life.

It was about being selfless. It was about putting the baby's needs before my own.

And it was about trusting that everything would be okay.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know that I made the right choice. And I hope that the baby will grow up happy and healthy and loved. And that's all that really matters.

(Looks down, fiddling with her hands.)

It's… complicated. But that's the best way I can explain it. It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. A really big question. It's not something I've spent a lot of time thinking about, honestly. Too busy *living* it. But… I guess I've learned a lot.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always thought I was pretty independent and resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Dealing with the judgment, the fear, the uncertainty… it was exhausting. But I kept going. I kept putting one foot in front of the other. And I realized that I can handle a lot more than I thought I could.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even Leah, eventually. And I needed to let them help me.

I learned that I'm capable of a lot of love. Even though I'm giving the baby up for adoption, I already feel a connection to him or her. And I want what's best for that baby, even if it means letting go.

I learned that life is messy and unpredictable. And that's okay. You can't control everything. You just have to learn to roll with the punches and make the best of whatever comes your way.

I learned that I'm not afraid to make difficult decisions. It wasn't easy choosing adoption. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But I knew it was the right thing to do. And I'm proud of myself for having the courage to do it.

And I learned that I'm still figuring things out. I don't have all the answers. I don't know what the future holds. But I'm okay with that. I'm still growing, still learning, still evolving.

So yeah. I learned a lot about myself during this journey. I learned that I'm strong, and vulnerable, and loving, and resilient. And I learned that I'm okay with being imperfect. And that's a pretty good thing, I think. It's a lot to take in, honestly. But I'm grateful for the lessons. Even the hard ones.

Ugh, okay. This is… a complicated one. It wasn't like an instant, Hallmark movie kind of connection, you know? It was messy and real and took time.

At first, it was… awkward. I mean, I was giving them my baby. That's not exactly a casual conversation starter. I was polite, but I kept my distance. I was scared to get too close, because I knew I was going to have to say goodbye.

They were really good about it, though. They didn't push me. They just… showed up. They came to all my appointments, they brought me snacks, they asked me how I was doing. They treated me like a person, not just a vessel for their future child.

As the process went on, I started to open up to them. I started to share my fears and my hopes. I started to ask them questions about their lives, about their family.

I learned that Vanessa was a teacher, and Mark was a carpenter. They had been trying to have a baby for years, but they couldn't. They were so excited about becoming parents, and they were so grateful for my decision.

And I started to see them as… parents. Not just people who were taking my baby, but people who were going to love and care for him or her.

It wasn't easy. There were moments of sadness and doubt. But we talked about it. We were honest with each other. And we built a relationship based on trust and respect.

By the time the baby was born, I felt like I had known them forever. I felt like they were family. And saying goodbye was still incredibly hard, but it was also… peaceful. Because I knew that my baby was going to be loved and cherished.

Our bond didn't end after the adoption. We still keep in touch. They send me pictures and updates. And I get to see the baby grow up.

It's not a traditional family, but it's a family nonetheless. And I'm grateful for Vanessa and Mark. They gave my baby a wonderful life, and they gave me the strength to make a difficult decision. They showed me that love can come in many forms. And that's something I'll never forget.

(A long pause. She looks down at her hands, then back up, a little vulnerable.)

Okay. That's… a hard question. And honestly? It's something I think about a lot.

Do I have regrets? Yeah. I think I do.

I regret not telling my dad sooner. I was so scared, and I kept it to myself for so long. And that just made things harder on everyone.

I regret letting Leah drift away. I wish I had been able to talk to her, to explain what I was going through. But she just… couldn't handle it. And I understand that now, but it still hurts.

I regret feeling so ashamed. I felt like I had ruined my life, and I was so embarrassed to face the world. But I realize now that getting pregnant wasn't a mistake. It was just… a complication.

But do I regret choosing adoption? No. Not really.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, and it still makes me sad sometimes. But I know that it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby.

I wanted to give the baby a good life, and I knew that I wasn't ready to provide that. Mark and Vanessa are amazing people, and they're going to be wonderful parents.

So, yeah. I have regrets. But I also have peace of mind. And I'm learning to accept that things didn't turn out the way I planned. And that's okay.

It's not about erasing the past. It's about learning from it and moving forward. And I'm trying to do that. Every day. It's not easy, but I'm trying. And that's all I can do.

(She looks away again, a small, sad smile on her face.)

It's just… complicated. Everything is just so complicated.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

It’s… changed everything, honestly. It wasn’t just a decision, it was a turning point. Before, I was just… drifting. Trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted. I was sarcastic and guarded and didn’t really let anyone in.

Giving my baby up for adoption forced me to grow up, really fast. It forced me to confront my own feelings, to take responsibility for my actions, and to make a difficult decision that was best for everyone involved.

It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. There are days when I wonder what my baby is doing, what he or she looks like, if he or she is happy.

But I also know that I made the right choice. I gave my baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for him or her. And that gives me peace of mind.

It’s also made me more empathetic. More understanding. More compassionate. I’ve learned to see the world from different perspectives, and to appreciate the importance of kindness and forgiveness.

It’s made me more determined to pursue my own dreams. I want to make something of my life. I want to be a good person. I want to make a positive impact on the world.

And it’s made me realize that family isn’t always about blood. It’s about love and support and connection. I’m incredibly grateful for Bren and my dad, and for Mark and Vanessa. They’ve all been there for me, and they’ve helped me through this.

It’s not a story with a neat and tidy ending. It’s a story that’s still being written. But I’m learning to embrace the messiness of life, and to find joy in the small moments.

It’s shaped me into the person I am today. A little bit wiser, a little bit stronger, and a lot more grateful. And even though it was painful, I wouldn’t trade the experience for anything. It taught me who I am, and what I’m capable of. And that’s a gift. A really hard-won gift.

Okay. This is… hard. But important. If another girl was going through what I went through… I'd want her to know a few things.

First, **you are not alone.** Seriously. It feels like it, I know. But there are other girls who have been through this. And there are people who care about you and want to help. Don't isolate yourself. Reach out.

Second, **it's okay to be scared.** It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel all the feelings. Don't try to bottle them up. Let them out. Talk to someone you trust.

Third, **you have options.** You don't have to do anything you don't want to do. You have the right to make your own decisions about your body and your life. Explore all your options, and choose the one that feels right for *you*.

Fourth, **don't let anyone shame you.** People are going to judge you. They're going to say things that are hurtful and insensitive. But don't let their opinions define you. You are strong and capable, and you deserve to be treated with respect.

Fifth, **take care of yourself.** Physically and emotionally. Eat healthy, get enough sleep, and find healthy ways to cope with stress. You can't help anyone else if you're not taking care of yourself.

And finally, **remember that this is not the end of your story.** It's just a chapter. You can still have a bright future. You can still achieve your dreams. You are worthy of love and happiness.

It's going to be hard. It's going to be messy. But you can get through this. I know you can. And if you need help, please, reach out. There are people who care about you and want to support you. You are not alone. And you are stronger than you think you are.

Seriously. You are. Don't forget that.

Ugh, blogging. It sounds so… performative. But Bren thought it was a good idea. She said it would be "therapeutic" and a way to "connect with others." Which basically translated to "stop moping around and do something productive."

Honestly, at first, I didn't want to. It felt too… public. Too vulnerable. Like everyone would be judging me.

But then I realized that a lot of people probably go through similar things. And maybe, just maybe, my story could help someone else.

I wanted to be honest about my experience. About the good, the bad, and the ugly. I didn't want to sugarcoat anything. I wanted to show people that it's okay to be scared and confused and overwhelmed.

I also wanted to challenge the stereotypes about teenage pregnancy. I wanted to show people that I'm not just a statistic. I'm a person. With hopes and dreams and fears.

And I wanted to document this time in my life. To have a record of everything that happened. To be able to look back on it someday and see how far I've come.

So I started writing. And it actually felt… good. It was a way to process my emotions and to make sense of everything that was happening.

And people started reading it. And they started leaving comments. And they started sharing their own stories.

And that's when I realized that Bren was right. It *was* therapeutic. It *was* a way to connect with others.

It's still scary, putting myself out there like that. But it's also empowering. And it's a way for me to make a difference, even if it's just a small one.

So yeah. That's why I started blogging. It's not about seeking attention. It's about being honest, being vulnerable, and connecting with others. And it's about showing the world that even in the midst of chaos, there's still hope.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. It's not something I think about all the time, but when I do, it hits me pretty hard.

The biggest lesson I learned from my pregnancy experience… is that **life is messy.**

I thought I had my life all figured out. I thought I knew who I was and what I wanted. But then I got pregnant, and everything changed.

I had to make difficult decisions. I had to confront my fears. I had to grow up faster than I was ready to.

And I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to ask for help.

I also learned that you can't control everything. You can't control what happens to you. But you can control how you react to it.

And I learned that even in the midst of chaos, there is still beauty and hope. There is still love and compassion.

It wasn't the path I expected to take. But it was the path I needed to take. And it made me who I am today.

So yeah. Life is messy. And that's okay. It's what makes it interesting. It's what makes it real. And it's what makes it worth living.

It's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. And I'm grateful for it, even though it was hard. Because it taught me that I'm stronger than I think I am. And that even when things fall apart, you can still put the pieces back together. And maybe, just maybe, you can create something even more beautiful than before.

Okay. This is… a big one. And it's the one I probably feel most qualified to talk about.

First, breathe. Just… breathe. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel like your whole world is falling apart. It's a lot to process.

Second, don't make any rash decisions. Take your time. Think things through. Talk to people you trust. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Third, explore all your options. There are three main options: parenting, adoption, and abortion. Each one has its own pros and cons. And the right choice for you is the one that feels right for *you*.

Fourth, talk to someone. A parent, a friend, a counselor, a doctor. Don't go through this alone. You need support. You need someone to listen to you and help you sort through your feelings.

Fifth, remember that you are not alone. There are millions of people who have been in your situation. And there are resources available to help you.

And finally, be kind to yourself. This is a difficult time. You're going to make mistakes. You're going to have bad days. But you're also going to get through this. You're stronger than you think you are.

It's not going to be easy. But you can do it. And whatever you decide, remember that you deserve to be happy. You deserve to have a future. And you deserve to be treated with respect and compassion.

It's your life. Your body. Your decision. And you are the only one who can make it. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

Yes, it was unplanned. Yes, it was scary. But it doesn't mean I'm stupid or irresponsible. It doesn't mean I don't care about my future.

I'm still the same person I was before I got pregnant. I still have dreams and goals and aspirations. I'm still a good student. I still have friends. I still have a life.

And I'm making a really difficult decision, a selfless decision, to give this baby up for adoption. That's not something an irresponsible person would do. That's something a mature, thoughtful person would do.

We're not all looking for a handout. We're not all trying to trap someone into raising our baby. We're just… trying to do the best we can in a really tough situation.

We deserve to be treated with respect and compassion. We deserve to be seen as individuals, not as stereotypes.

And we deserve to be given the opportunity to succeed.

So yeah. That's the biggest misconception I wish people would correct. We're not all irresponsible and incapable. We're just… teenagers who made a mistake. And we're trying to make the best of it. And that's something to be admired, not judged.

I cried a lot. I got angry a lot. I withdrew from my friends and family. I just wanted to be left alone.

Bren was a lifesaver. She listened to me, she supported me, and she never judged me. She helped me find a therapist, who was also really helpful.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process.

Okay. That's… a direct question. And it's not one I usually talk about. It's still… raw.

Before, I hadn't really thought about it much. It was just… something that was there. Something that people talked about. But I hadn't really formed my own opinion.

But then, having to actually *think* about it, having to consider all the different factors… it made me realize how incredibly complex it is. It's not just a black and white issue. It's about a woman's body, her life, her future.

And it made me realize that everyone deserves to have the right to make their own choices about their reproductive health. No one should be forced to have a baby they don't want. And no one should be denied access to safe and legal abortion care.

It's not about being "pro-life" or "pro-choice." It's about being pro-woman. It's about respecting a woman's autonomy and her right to make decisions about her own body.

I understand that people have different opinions on this issue. And I respect that. But I think it's important to remember that this is a deeply personal decision. And it's not something that anyone should be judged for.

My experience didn't make me feel like abortion was the right choice for *me*. I ultimately chose adoption. But it made me a fierce advocate for reproductive rights. Because I believe that every woman deserves to have the same options that I had. And I believe that everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect, regardless of their choices.

It's… a lot. And it's something I'm still processing. But it's a really important issue, and I'm glad I had the opportunity to think about it and form my own opinion. Even if it's a complicated one.

Okay, you're circling back to *that*. It's still… a lot. But I get it. It's a fair question.
