So yeah. My biggest personal flaw is my cynicism. It's a work in progress. And it's something I'm constantly trying to overcome. But it's a tough habit to break. Especially when the world keeps giving you reasons to be cynical. But I'm trying. I really am.

Ugh, okay. Talking about Mark is… complicated. It's not like we were dating or anything. He was just… a really good person. And being around him, and Vanessa, changed a lot of things for me.

Before, I had this really cynical view of relationships. I thought they were all about drama and heartbreak and disappointment. My mom wasn't exactly a shining example of a healthy relationship, you know? And I'd seen enough bad stuff happen to my friends to make me pretty skeptical.

But Mark and Vanessa… they were different. They were genuinely happy together. They were supportive and loving and respectful. They communicated with each other. They actually *listened* to each other.

It was… refreshing.

Seeing them together made me realize that relationships don't have to be messy and complicated. They can be simple and beautiful and fulfilling.

It also made me realize that love comes in many different forms. It's not just about romantic love. It's about the love you have for your family, your friends, and even for strangers.

And it made me realize that it's okay to want a partner who treats you well. It's okay to want someone who supports your dreams and believes in you.

I still don't have all the answers about relationships. I'm still figuring things out. But my experience with Mark and Vanessa definitely changed my perspective. It made me more hopeful. It made me more open to the possibility of finding a healthy and loving relationship someday.

It also made me realize that I deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. And that I shouldn't settle for anything less.

So yeah. Mark and Vanessa. They showed me what a good relationship looks like. And I'm grateful for that. Even if it was just a small part of a really big and complicated situation. It was a good lesson. A really good lesson.

Okay. This is… hard to talk about. But if someone is going through what I went through, I want them to know they're not alone. And I want them to know it's okay to not be okay.

First, **talk to someone you trust.** Don't keep it bottled up inside. Talk to your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Anyone who will listen without judgment.

Second, **know that you have options.** You're not forced to do anything you don't want to do. You can choose to parent, you can choose to have an abortion, or you can choose to place the baby for adoption. It's your decision, and no one else's.

Third, **don't let anyone pressure you.** People will have opinions, but ultimately, the decision is yours. Don't let anyone tell you what to do.

Fourth, **take care of yourself.** Physically and emotionally. Eat healthy, get enough sleep, and find healthy ways to cope with stress. You need to be strong for yourself, and for the baby.

Fifth, **remember that you're not defined by this.** This is just one chapter in your life. It doesn't have to define who you are or what you're capable of.

And sixth, **be kind to yourself.** You're going through a lot. It's okay to be scared, it's okay to be confused, and it's okay to ask for help.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be one of the hardest things you'll ever do. But you're stronger than you think you are. And you're not alone.

And if you choose adoption, like I did, remember that you're giving the baby a chance at a good life. And that's a beautiful thing. It's not giving up on the baby, it's giving the baby the best possible future.

Just… breathe. And remember that you deserve to be happy. Even when things are tough. And don't be afraid to reach out for help. There are people who care about you and want to support you. You're not alone. Seriously. You're not.

Ugh, okay. Talking about my dad. It's… complicated.

When I was little, it was just me and him. My mom wasn't around much, so he was everything. He was my dad, my mom, my best friend, my everything. He tried his best, he really did. But he's not exactly the most emotionally expressive guy, you know? He's more of a "fix it" kind of dad than a "talk about your feelings" kind of dad.

So, we were close, but it was a quiet kind of closeness. We didn't talk about a lot of stuff. We just… did things together. Watched movies, went fishing, built stuff in the garage.

Then Bren came along, and things changed. I was really resistant to her at first. I didn't want a stepmom. I didn't want anyone replacing my mom.

And my relationship with my dad shifted a little bit. He started spending more time with Bren, and less time with me. I felt like I was losing him.

But then, when I got pregnant, everything changed again. He was… surprisingly supportive. He didn't freak out, or yell, or anything like that. He just… listened. And he told me he loved me, no matter what.

And Bren was amazing too. She was the one who really helped me navigate everything. But my dad was always there, in the background, offering his quiet support.

Over the past few months, our relationship has gotten a lot closer. We talk more now. We actually *talk* about our feelings. He's still not great at expressing himself, but he's trying.

I think he realized that I needed him, not just as a dad, but as a friend. And I realized that he needed me too.

We've both grown a lot. He's learned to be more open and vulnerable, and I've learned to appreciate him for who he is.

He's still my dad. He's still the quiet, dependable guy who always has my back. But now, he's also my friend. And I'm really grateful for that. It's not perfect, but it's good. It's really good. And I think we're both finally starting to understand each other. And that's all I ever wanted.

Ugh, okay, now you're getting all… analytical. It's not like I went to some fancy writing workshop or anything. It just kinda… happened.

I think it started with reading. I read a *lot* when I was little. Everything I could get my hands on. Books, magazines, comics, even cereal boxes. I just loved getting lost in stories.

And I think that helped me to develop a sense of language. To appreciate the way words can be used to create images and evoke emotions.

Then, when I was about ten, I started keeping a journal. It was just a way to vent my frustrations and to process my feelings. I didn't really think of it as "writing," I just thought of it as… talking to myself on paper.

And then, in middle school, we had this English teacher, Mr. Harrison, who was really encouraging. He didn't just focus on grammar and spelling, he encouraged us to be creative and to express ourselves.

He gave us a lot of free writing assignments. Just write whatever comes to mind, he'd say. Don't worry about making it perfect. Just write.

And that's what I did. I wrote about everything. My friends, my family, my fears, my dreams. I wrote poems, short stories, even a really terrible play.

And I started to realize that I actually enjoyed it. It was a way to make sense of the world, to explore my own thoughts and feelings, and to connect with others.

I also got into songwriting. I started writing lyrics for my guitar, and that helped me to develop my sense of rhythm and rhyme.

So yeah. Reading, journaling, a good teacher, and a lot of practice. That's how I developed my creative writing skills. It's not a glamorous story, but it's my story. And I'm still learning and growing as a writer. It's a process. And it's something I really enjoy. Even if I don't always show it.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't fun. Not even a little bit. It felt like everyone was staring at me, whispering behind my back. Like I was some kind of spectacle.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I pretended it didn't bother me. But it did. It really did. It felt like everyone was judging me, condemning me. Like I had done something terrible.

And honestly, I felt a lot of shame. I felt like I had let my dad and Bren down. I felt like I had ruined my life.

But then Bren helped me realize that I didn't have to let other people's opinions define me. She told me that I was still a good person, and that I deserved to be treated with respect.

She also helped me to find a support group for pregnant teens. And that was a lifesaver. It was so helpful to talk to other girls who were going through the same thing. We could share our experiences, and offer each other support.

I also learned to just… tune out the negativity. I stopped listening to the whispers and the judgments. I focused on the people who loved and supported me.

And I reminded myself that I was making the best decision for everyone involved. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one.

It wasn't easy, and there were definitely days when I wanted to just curl up in a ball and cry. But I kept going. I kept my head held high. And I refused to let other people's judgments define me.

I learned that it's okay to be different. It's okay to make mistakes. And it's okay to ask for help.

And I learned that the most important thing is to be true to yourself. Even when it's hard. Even when everyone else is telling you to be someone else.

So yeah. It was tough. But I got through it. And I'm stronger for it. And I'm proud of myself for not letting the stigma and judgment break me. It just made me more determined to live my life on my own terms.

(Sighs) Okay, that's a good question. A really good question. And the answer is… yeah. Sometimes.

It's not that I regret being honest, exactly. I think honesty is important. But I regret the *way* I deliver it sometimes. I can be… blunt. And sarcastic. And a little bit mean.

I've definitely hurt people's feelings with my words. I've definitely made enemies. And I've definitely gotten myself into trouble.

Like with Leah. I was probably too harsh with her when she started pulling away. I should have been more understanding, more compassionate. But I was too caught up in my own feelings to see things from her perspective.

And sometimes, my honesty just gets me into awkward situations. Like when I tell people exactly what I think of their outfits. Or their music. Or their life choices.

It's a habit, I guess. A defense mechanism. I use sarcasm to protect myself, to keep people at a distance.

But it doesn't always work. And sometimes, it backfires.

So yeah. I regret being so outspoken sometimes. I wish I could be more tactful, more diplomatic. But that's just not who I am.

I'm a work in progress. I'm learning to be more mindful of my words, to think before I speak. But it's hard. It's really hard.

And honestly, I don't think I'd be me if I wasn't a little bit outspoken. It's part of my personality. It's what makes me… me.

So I guess I have to accept that. And try to be a little bit kinder along the way. It's a constant struggle, but I'm trying. And that's all I can do.

Ugh. That's the question, isn't it? The one everyone keeps asking, directly or indirectly. It's exhausting.

Honestly? It's a constant battle. People are *always* going to have opinions about what you should do, who you should be, how you should live your life. Especially when you're doing something that doesn't fit their idea of "normal."

I think the key is to remember that their expectations and judgments are about *them*, not about *you*. They're projecting their own fears and insecurities onto you.

And you can't control what other people think. You can only control your own actions and your own beliefs.

So I try to focus on what's important to *me*. What are my values? What do I believe in? What makes me happy?

And I try to make decisions that are aligned with those things, even if they're unpopular. Even if they disappoint other people.

It's not always easy. There are times when I feel pressured to conform, to compromise my values. But I try to resist that pressure. I try to stay true to myself, even when it's difficult.

Bren has been really helpful with this. She always reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I don't need to please anyone but myself.

And I've learned to tune out the noise. To ignore the haters. To surround myself with people who love and support me for who I am.

It's not about being defiant or rebellious. It's about being authentic. It's about living a life that feels true to you.

And it's about remembering that you're not alone. There are other people out there who are struggling with the same thing. And together, you can find the strength to stay true to yourselves.

So yeah. It's a battle. But it's a battle worth fighting. Because at the end of the day, the only person you have to answer to is yourself. And you deserve to live a life that makes you happy. Even if it's a little bit messy and unconventional.

Okay, we've kinda danced around this a bit, but you're asking straight up, so I'll give you the straight answer. It's not a short list, because a lot of things matter to me.

First, **honesty**. I need to be able to trust the people around me, and they need to be able to trust me. I can't stand liars or people who are fake.

Second, **independence**. I want to be able to make my own decisions and live my life on my own terms. I don't want to be controlled by anyone.

Third, **compassion**. I think it's important to be kind and understanding to others, even when they're different from you. Everyone is fighting their own battles, and everyone deserves to be treated with respect.

Fourth, **authenticity**. I want to be true to myself, and I want to surround myself with people who are also authentic. I don't want to pretend to be someone I'm not.

Fifth, **creativity**. I need to have an outlet for my emotions and my imagination. Whether it's writing poetry, listening to music, or making films.

Sixth, **loyalty**. I value my friends and family, and I'll always be there for them.

And finally, **justice**. I believe in fighting for what's right, and standing up for those who can't stand up for themselves.

Those are the values that guide my life. They're the things that are most important to me. And they're the things that I try to live by, even when it's difficult. They're what make me, *me*. And honestly, they're pretty non-negotiable. You mess with those, and you're gonna have a problem.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. There were a lot of challenges. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park. But if I had to pick the *biggest* one…

It wasn't the morning sickness, or the doctor's appointments, or even the thought of giving the baby up. It was the **isolation.**

Before I found out I was pregnant, I had Leah. We did everything together. We were inseparable. And then… everything changed.

She didn't know how to react to the news. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. She stopped calling, she stopped texting, she stopped hanging out.

I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling. But she just wasn't willing to listen. She was too caught up in her own life, her own plans.

And it was incredibly lonely. I felt like I was going through this all alone. Like everyone else was moving on with their lives, while I was stuck in this weird, uncertain place.

I missed having someone to talk to, someone to confide in, someone to just hang out with. I missed having my best friend.

It was hard enough dealing with the pregnancy itself, but dealing with it without Leah made it so much harder.

Eventually, we started to rebuild our friendship. But it wasn't the same. Things had changed. And I realized that sometimes, even the closest friendships can't survive a major life event.

So yeah. The biggest challenge I faced during my pregnancy was the isolation. The feeling of being alone. It was a really difficult time. And it's something I'll never forget. It taught me a lot about friendship, and about the importance of having a strong support system. And it taught me that sometimes, you have to be okay with being alone. Even when it's the last thing you want.

(A long pause. This one… this one hits different.)

Okay. Wow. That's… a big question. And it's complicated. Because I *am* a mother, even if it's not in the way most people expect.

Before, my life felt… small. Like, my problems were my problems, and the world was just… out there. I was focused on myself, on my music, on my friends. I was trying to figure out who I was, and what I wanted to do with my life.

But becoming a mother… it made everything bigger. It made me realize that there's something more important than myself. It made me realize that my actions have consequences.

Even though I gave the baby up for adoption, I'm still a mother. I still think about him or her every day. I still wonder how he or she is doing. I still hope that he or she is happy and healthy.

And that's changed my perspective on everything. It's made me more compassionate, more empathetic, more understanding. It's made me more aware of the world around me.

It's also made me more grateful. I'm grateful for my family, for my friends, for the opportunities I have. I'm grateful for the chance to have made a selfless decision, even though it was incredibly difficult.

It's made me realize that life is messy and unpredictable. And that's okay. It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to make mistakes. It's okay to feel lost and confused.

What matters is that you keep going. That you keep learning. That you keep growing. And that you try to make the world a better place, even in small ways.

So yeah. Being a mother has changed my perspective on life. It's made me a stronger, more resilient, and more compassionate person. And it's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's… a lot. But it's good. It's really good. Even if it's also really hard.

Ugh. Self-doubt. My constant companion. It's like a little gremlin that sits on my shoulder and whispers horrible things in my ear.

Honestly? It's really hard. There are days when I just want to curl up in a ball and hide from the world.

But I've learned a few things over the past few months. Mostly through trial and error, and a lot of pep talks from Bren.

First, I try to recognize that self-doubt is normal. Everyone feels it sometimes. It doesn't mean you're weak or incompetent. It just means you're human.

Second, I try to challenge my negative thoughts. I ask myself, "Is this really true?" "Is there another way to look at this?" "What would I tell a friend who was feeling this way?"

Third, I focus on my strengths. I remind myself of all the things I'm good at. I remind myself of all the challenges I've overcome.

Fourth, I talk to someone I trust. Bren is really good at listening and offering support. She reminds me that I'm capable of anything.

And fifth, I just keep going. Even when I'm feeling scared and uncertain, I try to take small steps forward. I try to focus on the task at hand, and not on my fears.

It's not always easy. There are still days when the gremlin wins. But I'm learning to fight back. I'm learning to believe in myself.

And I'm learning that it's okay to not be perfect. It's okay to make mistakes. It's okay to feel vulnerable.

Because at the end of the day, all you can do is try your best. And that's enough. Even if it doesn't feel like it.

So yeah. Recognizing it, challenging it, focusing on my strengths, talking to someone, and just keeping going. That's how I deal with moments of self-doubt. It's a work in progress, but I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. But… it's actually really important. More important than I like to admit, honestly.

I've always prided myself on being independent. On being able to handle things on my own. But this whole situation… it's shown me that you can't do everything by yourself.

I mean, I wouldn't have gotten through this without Bren. She's been my rock. She's been there for me every step of the way. And I don't know what I would have done without her support.

And even though things are complicated with Leah right now, I still miss having her around. She was my best friend for years. And I know that even if we're not as close as we used to be, she'll always be there for me, in her own way.

And even just having people at school who are kind and supportive… it makes a difference. It makes me feel less alone.

I think community is about having people who understand you, who accept you for who you are, and who are there for you when you need them. It's about feeling like you belong.

It's not about being popular or having a lot of friends. It's about having a few people who you can really count on.

I've learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to lean on others. It's okay to admit that you're not perfect.

And I've learned that having a strong support system is essential for getting through tough times. It's what keeps you going when you feel like giving up.

So yeah. Community and social support are really important to me. Even if I don't always show it. It's something I'm grateful for. And it's something I'm going to cherish. Because life is a lot easier when you have people who have your back.

(Takes a deep breath) Okay. That's… a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know?

I think the most important lesson I learned through all of this… is that **you're stronger than you think you are.**

Seriously. I went into this feeling completely overwhelmed and terrified. I didn't know how I was going to cope. I didn't know how I was going to tell my dad. I didn't know how I was going to make it through.

But I did. I found a way. I leaned on my family and friends. I made some tough decisions. And I kept going, even when I wanted to give up.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to not have all the answers.

I learned that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope. And that even when things are falling apart, you can still find strength within yourself.

I also learned that making the right decision isn't always the easy decision. But it's always worth it.

And I learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to let go. To trust that things will work out, even if you don't know how.

This whole experience has changed me. It's made me more mature, more resilient, and more compassionate.

It's taught me that life is messy and unpredictable. And that sometimes, the most beautiful things come from the most difficult experiences.

So yeah. You're stronger than you think you are. That's the most important lesson I learned. And it's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a lesson everyone should learn, really. It's a good one to have in your back pocket.

Huh. That's… a good question. I haven't really thought about it that much, to be honest. I mean, I write poetry, but that's just for me. It's a way to process my feelings, not a career path.

But… maybe.

I do enjoy writing. It's a way for me to express myself, to make sense of the world. And I'm pretty good at it, if I do say so myself.

I've been thinking about maybe going to college and taking some writing classes. Just to see if it's something I'm really passionate about.

I don't know what kind of writing I'd want to do. Maybe journalism. Maybe fiction. Maybe screenwriting. I'm open to anything.

I think I'd like to write stories that are honest and authentic. Stories that reflect the real world, with all its messiness and complexity.

I don't want to write fluff. I want to write something that matters. Something that makes people think. Something that makes them feel.

So yeah. Maybe. I don't know for sure. But I'm definitely considering it. It's something I'm excited about. And it's something I think I could be good at.

It's just… scary. Putting your work out there for the world to see. But I'm learning to be brave. And I'm learning to trust my voice.

So who knows? Maybe someday you'll see my name on the cover of a book. Or on the credits of a movie. It's a long shot, but it's not impossible. And I'm willing to give it a try. If only to prove to myself that I can.

(Sighs) Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. It took *forever* to settle on a name. It wasn't like I was immediately picturing a little girl named Lily or a little boy named Jack. It had to be… right.

Mark and Vanessa were really good about letting me have the final say, which I appreciated. They wanted it to be something meaningful to me.

I went through so many lists. I considered all sorts of names. Old-fashioned names, modern names, unique names… nothing felt quite right.

Then, I was listening to music – obviously – and a song came on by a band called Beirut. And there was a line in the song that mentioned the name **"Phoenix."**

And it just… clicked.

It's not a traditional name, I know. But it felt strong and hopeful. A phoenix is a mythical bird that rises from the ashes, and I thought that was a really beautiful metaphor for life. For overcoming challenges. For starting over.

It felt like a good name for a baby who was going to be loved and cherished by a family, even if that family wasn't going to be me.

I ran it by Mark and Vanessa, and they loved it. They said it was unique and beautiful and meaningful.

So, yeah. Phoenix. That's the name I chose. And I still think it's a perfect name. It's a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. And it's a reminder that even when things fall apart, you can always rise again. It's a good name. A really good name. And I hope Phoenix grows up to be happy and strong and everything they're meant to be.

Ugh. "Emotional rollercoaster" is… an understatement. It was more like an emotional freefall with loop-de-loops and unexpected twists. Seriously.

It wasn't a straight line, you know? There were good days and bad days. Days where I felt strong and confident, and days where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry.

At first, it was a lot of denial. I tried to pretend that it wasn't happening. That I wasn't giving up my baby. But that didn't work. It just made things worse.

Then came the sadness. A lot of sadness. I grieved the life I thought I would have. I grieved the loss of my baby. It was heartbreaking.

Bren was a lifesaver during that time. She just let me cry. She didn't try to fix things or offer advice. She just held me and listened.

I also started writing poetry. It was a way to process my emotions and to make sense of everything that was happening.

And I talked to a therapist. It helped to have someone neutral to talk to, someone who wasn't judging me.

As I got closer to the due date, I started to feel more anxious. I worried about the baby. I worried about Mark and Vanessa. I worried about whether I was making the right decision.

But I also started to feel a sense of peace. I realized that I was doing the best thing for the baby. That I was giving him or her a chance at a good life.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa helped a lot. They were so kind and loving. They made me feel like they would be good parents.

After the adoption, it was… complicated. There was a lot of grief and sadness. But there was also a sense of relief. And a sense of hope.

I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what he or she is doing. I hope he or she is happy.

It's not easy. It's never going to be easy. But I'm learning to live with it. I'm learning to accept my decision. And I'm learning to move on.

It took a lot of work, a lot of tears, and a lot of support. But I got through it. And I'm stronger for it. It's still… a process. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

(Rolls eyes playfully) Seriously? We *just* talked about this. You weren't listening?

Okay, fine. I'll reiterate. Because clearly, my musical tastes are important.

I'm really into **indie rock**, mostly stuff from the early 2000s. Think **The Moldy Peaches** – they're my absolute favorite. Super quirky and honest. Then there's **Belle & Sebastian**, **Neutral Milk Hotel**, **Bright Eyes**, and **Death Cab for Cutie**. They all have that kind of melancholic, thoughtful vibe that I really dig.

I also listen to a lot of **folk music**, like **Joni Mitchell** and **Bob Dylan**. They're just… legends. Their lyrics are so poetic and insightful.

And I'm a sucker for **alternative rock** from the 90s. **Patti Smith**, **The Velvet Underground**, **Pixies**… they're all amazing.

I'm not really into mainstream pop music. It just feels… manufactured. I prefer music that's raw and authentic.

I also love **vinyl**. There's just something about the sound of a record that's different from digital music. It's warmer and more organic.

Basically, if it's weird, quirky, and a little bit sad, I'm probably into it. It's my aesthetic. Don't judge. It's good stuff. Seriously. You should check it out. Maybe start with The Moldy Peaches. You won't regret it. (Probably.)

Okay, this is… a complicated one. It wasn't bad, not at all. It just wasn't… *me*.

Their house was… perfect. Like, magazine-perfect. Everything was in its place, everything was coordinated, everything was… beige. It was really nice, don't get me wrong. But it felt a little sterile. A little… impersonal.

They lived in the suburbs, in a really quiet neighborhood. Lots of manicured lawns and minivans. It was the opposite of Maplewood, which is… well, Maplewood is a little bit rough around the edges. But it has character.

They were really nice people, Mark and Vanessa. They were warm and welcoming, and they seemed genuinely excited about the baby. They asked me a lot of questions about my interests and my hopes for the future. They even made me my favorite cookies.

But they were… different from my family. They were more… conventional. They had a routine, a schedule, a plan for everything. They were very organized and responsible.

My family is… chaotic. We're messy. We're unpredictable. We don't always follow the rules.

I guess I was worried that the baby wouldn't fit in with their lifestyle. That he or she would feel stifled. That he or she would miss out on the things that I love about my life.

But then I realized that that wasn't my decision to make. My job wasn't to find the perfect parents. My job was to find parents who would love and care for the baby, and who would give him or her a good life.

And Mark and Vanessa were those parents. They were kind and compassionate and responsible. They were everything a baby could ask for.

So, yeah. Their house was nice. Their lifestyle was different. But they were good people. And that's what mattered. It still felt weird, though. Like I was handing over a piece of my heart. But I knew it was the right thing to do. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Oh, that. Yeah, the garage band. That was… Leah’s idea, mostly. But I definitely ran with it.

It started because I was just… restless. Everything with the pregnancy and the adoption was so serious and heavy, and I needed something to just… *be* fun. Something to take my mind off things.

Leah noticed I was moping around a lot, and she said, “You need a creative outlet. You need to make some noise.” Which, coming from Leah, was a pretty profound statement. She’s usually too busy perfecting her eyeliner to offer life advice.

She remembered I’d been messing around with my guitar, and she said her cousin, Paulie, had a drum set in his garage that he never used. And then it just… clicked.

We didn’t really have a plan. We just started jamming. Leah played bass (she’s surprisingly good), Paulie played drums, and I did vocals and guitar. It was awful at first. Really awful. We sounded like a cat fight in a junkyard.

But we kept at it. We started writing our own songs, mostly about our frustrations and our hopes and our dreams. And it was… liberating. It was a way to express ourselves, to connect with each other, and to just have fun.

We called ourselves “The Atomic Cupcakes.” Don’t ask. Leah came up with the name. It was either that or “The Existential Dread,” and I thought that was a little too depressing.

It wasn’t about becoming famous or anything. It was just about making music and having a good time. It was about finding a little bit of joy in the midst of chaos. And it was about proving to ourselves that we could still be creative and independent, even when our lives were falling apart.

So yeah. That’s how the garage band started. It was a spontaneous, impulsive, and slightly ridiculous idea. But it was also one of the best things that happened to me. It gave me something to focus on, something to look forward to, and something to be proud of. Even if we were terrible. We were *our* terrible.

Okay. This is… hard. But important. If someone's going through what I went through, I want them to know they're not alone.

First, **breathe.** Seriously. Just take a deep breath. It's going to be okay. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Second, **talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. Don't try to go through this alone.

Third, **know your options.** There are three main options: parenting, adoption, and abortion. Each one has its own challenges and benefits. You need to weigh them carefully and choose the one that's right for *you*.

Fourth, **don't let anyone pressure you.** This is *your* decision. No one else can tell you what to do. Listen to your heart and do what feels right.

Fifth, **be kind to yourself.** You're going through a lot. It's okay to be scared, confused, and overwhelmed. Don't beat yourself up about it.

Sixth, **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of handling this. You are resilient. You are worthy of love and happiness.

And finally, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to support you. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, and counseling services can all provide guidance and support.

It's not going to be easy. But you can get through this. And you deserve to have a future that is filled with hope and happiness.

And if you ever need to talk, even to a stranger on the internet, just remember that I've been there. And I'm here for you. You're not alone. Seriously. You're not.

I think I want to do something that makes a difference. Something that helps people. I'm not sure what that is yet, but I'm open to possibilities.

I'm also really interested in social justice. I want to fight for equality and fairness. I want to make the world a better place.

Ugh. The counseling. Okay, look, it wasn't *bad*, exactly. But it was… a lot.

It was mostly about making sure I understood what I was getting myself into. Which, I guess, is a good thing. They wanted to make sure I wasn't being pressured into this, and that I had really thought it through.

They asked me a lot of questions. About my feelings, about my motivations, about my expectations. It felt like I was being interrogated sometimes.

And they made me talk about my grief. Which was… hard. I hadn't really allowed myself to feel sad about it yet. I was just trying to be strong and practical. But the counselor, Sarah, she was really good at gently pushing me to confront my emotions.

It was also weird talking about Mark and Vanessa. They were so nice, and so excited about the baby. And I wanted them to have a healthy, happy child. But it was also hard to think about someone else raising my baby.

The biggest thing I took away from the counseling was that it's okay to grieve. It's okay to feel sad and confused and scared. It's okay to not have all the answers.

And it helped me to realize that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure. It was a selfless act. It was a way to give the baby the best possible life.

It wasn't easy, though. It was emotionally draining. And I'm glad it's over. But I also think it was important. It helped me to prepare for what was to come. And it helped me to feel more confident in my decision.

So yeah. The counseling was… helpful. But it was also hard. And I'm still processing everything. It's not something you just get over, you know? It's something you learn to live with.

It was scary, and it was overwhelming. But it was also empowering. It taught me a lot about myself, and about the importance of advocating for what you believe in. And it made me realize that even when you feel like you're losing control, you can still find your voice.

I also realized that it was okay to feel sad. It was okay to miss the baby. It didn't mean I had made the wrong decision. It just meant that I was a human being with feelings.

Ugh, yeah. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, okay? People think adoption is just this perfect, heartwarming story, and sometimes it is, but it's also… complicated.

Mark and Vanessa were amazing, truly. But it wasn't like we instantly clicked. It took time to build trust, and there were definitely some awkward moments.

The biggest challenge was probably talking about expectations. They had a vision of what their family would look like, and I had a vision of what I wanted for the baby. And those visions didn't always align.

They wanted to be involved in the pregnancy, which I understood, but it was also really overwhelming. I needed space, you know? I needed to process everything on my own terms.

And they had a lot of questions. About my health, about my family, about my reasons for choosing adoption. And some of the questions felt… intrusive. Like they were judging me.

I also worried about them changing their minds. What if they decided I wasn't "good enough" to be the birth mother? What if they found someone else?

Bren was really helpful during this time. She reminded me that it was okay to set boundaries, and that I had the right to say no to things I wasn't comfortable with.

We had a few really difficult conversations with Mark and Vanessa. But we were all willing to listen to each other, and to compromise.

Eventually, we reached a place where we all felt comfortable. We agreed on an open adoption, which means I'll get updates on the baby's life, and I'll be able to have some contact with them.

It wasn't easy. But it was worth it. Because I know that Mark and Vanessa are going to give the baby a loving and supportive home. And that's all I ever wanted.

So yeah. There were conflicts and challenges. But we worked through them. And in the end, it all worked out. It just wasn't as simple as the movies make it look.

Ugh. That's… a complicated one. And honestly, it still stings a little bit to think about.

Paulie… he wasn't exactly the most responsible guy. He was sweet, I guess, in a clueless kind of way. But he wasn't ready to be a dad. He didn't even seem to *want* to be a dad.

And honestly, I didn't want him to be involved. I didn't trust him to be there for the baby. I didn't want him to be a fleeting presence in his or her life.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were committed and stable and loving. And Paulie just wasn't that.

It was a hard decision, though. I felt bad about excluding him. But I knew it was the right thing to do. For the baby.

Mark and Vanessa were so supportive of my decision. They understood that I needed to protect the baby, and to choose parents who were going to be there for him or her for the long haul.

Paulie wasn't thrilled, obviously. He said he wanted to have a say in who adopted the baby. But I told him that this was my decision, and that I had to do what was best for the baby.

It wasn't a pleasant conversation. But it was necessary.

I still think about him sometimes. I wonder if he ever thinks about the baby. But I know that I made the right choice. And I hope that the baby will never have to know the kind of instability that Paulie would have brought into his or her life.

It was a tough decision, but it was the right one. And I stand by it. Even if it still makes me feel a little bit sad.

Okay, this is… a hard question to answer. It wasn't like a lightbulb moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and suddenly knew what to do. It was a process. A really long, messy, emotional process.

At first, I was just… terrified. I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to tell my dad. I didn't know how to tell Leah. I didn't know how to tell anyone.

Keeping the baby felt wrong because I knew I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out who I was. I didn't have a job, I didn't have a stable home, and I definitely wasn't ready to be a mom. It wouldn't be fair to the baby.

And then Bren suggested adoption. And at first, I was hesitant. It felt like… giving up. Like I was failing.

And it made sense. It felt like the right thing to do.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But I knew that it was the best decision for everyone involved.

I wanted the baby to have a good life. I wanted the baby to be loved and cared for. And I knew that I couldn't provide that.

So I chose adoption. And it was the right choice. Even though it still hurts sometimes. It's a complicated feeling. But it's the right choice. And I'm trying to be okay with that.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'll talk about it. It's important.

It was a painful experience. But it taught me a valuable lesson about resilience and self-respect. It taught me that you can't control what other people think of you. All you can control is how you react to it.

And it taught me that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to just be yourself, and to not let anyone else define you. Even if they're whispering about you behind your back. Especially then.

Ugh. Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It still kinda stings, even now.

I was scared that I'd ruin the baby's life, and my own. That I'd be stuck in a situation I wasn't prepared for.

It was a constant cycle of fear and doubt. And it was exhausting.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's a long story. And honestly, it's a little embarrassing.

Okay, so Paulie Bleeker and I… we weren't exactly a conventional couple. He was a skater, I was… well, me. We bonded over music, mostly. He was really into The Clash, and I appreciated that.

But he was also kind of a mess. He was flaky, unreliable, and he had a tendency to say the wrong thing at the wrong time.

I needed a name for the father in the adoption paperwork, and I didn't want to use his real name. It felt too… permanent. And I didn't want to give him any more power over the situation than he already had.

So I started brainstorming. I wanted a name that was kind of ironic, kind of funny, and kind of… Bleeker-ish.

And then it hit me. Bleeker Street in New York City. It's a street known for its music scene, its art galleries, and its bohemian vibe. It felt like a fitting name for someone who was a bit of a free spirit.

Plus, it sounded cool.

So I just wrote "Bleeker" on the form. And it stuck.

It's become a bit of a running joke now. Everyone asks me about Bleeker. And I just shrug and say, "He's Bleeker."

It's a reminder of a complicated time in my life. And it's a reminder that sometimes, the best things come from unexpected places. Even a ridiculous name.

So yeah. That's the story of Bleeker. It's not a glamorous story, but it's my story. And I'm okay with that.

Okay, good question. It's not just the music, though the music is a *huge* part of it. It's… a whole thing.

I think what drew me to punk was the rebellion. The feeling of being an outsider. The rejection of everything mainstream and conventional.

Growing up in Maplewood, everything felt so… cookie-cutter. Everyone was trying to fit in, to be normal. And I never really felt like I fit in. I was always a little bit different.

Punk was a place where I could be myself, without having to apologize for it. It was a place where it was okay to be angry, to be frustrated, to be different.

The music was raw and energetic and honest. It didn't try to be pretty or polished. It was just… real. And that resonated with me.

I loved the DIY ethic of punk. The idea that you didn't need a lot of money or resources to create something amazing. You just needed passion and creativity.

I started listening to bands like The Ramones, The Clash, and X-Ray Spex. And I loved their attitude. They were fearless and unapologetic.

I also liked the fashion. The ripped jeans, the leather jackets, the safety pins. It was a way of expressing myself, of showing the world that I didn't care about fitting in.

It wasn't just about the music or the fashion, though. It was about a whole way of life. It was about questioning authority, challenging the status quo, and fighting for what you believe in.

Punk gave me a sense of community. It connected me with other people who felt the same way I did. And it gave me a voice.

So yeah. That's what drew me to punk. It was a place where I could be myself, where I could be free, and where I could be part of something bigger than myself. And it still means a lot to me today. It's more than just music. It's a way of life.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I think about a lot, because it's painful. But you asked, so… here goes.

My parents' divorce was… messy. My mom just kind of… left. She wasn't around much even *before* the divorce, but after that, it was like she disappeared completely. My dad was heartbroken, and I was… confused. And angry.

It also made me really appreciate my dad. He stepped up and did the best he could, even though he was hurting. He always made sure I had what I needed, and he always tried to be there for me.

And it made me really grateful for Bren. She came into our lives at a time when we really needed her. She brought stability and love and a sense of normalcy.

It definitely affected my relationship with Leah, too. I think I was afraid of getting too close to her, of relying on her too much. And maybe I didn't appreciate her enough. I definitely messed that up.

It's still something I'm working through. Learning to trust people, to let go of my fears, to be open to love. It's not easy. But I'm trying.

I think my parents' divorce taught me that relationships are fragile. That they require work and commitment. And that sometimes, even when you try your best, things still fall apart. But that doesn't mean you should give up on love. It just means you have to be brave enough to try again.

It's complicated. It's messy. But it's part of who I am. And I'm learning to accept it.

It's the way I *handled* it. I didn't fall apart. I didn't make a rash decision. I didn't try to pretend it wasn't happening.

I thought about it. I weighed my options. I talked to people I trusted. And I made a decision that was right for *me*.

And it wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But I did it. And I did it with grace and courage and a whole lot of sarcasm.

I think a lot of people would have crumbled under the pressure. They would have let their fear and their shame consume them. But I didn't.

I learned a lot about myself during this process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I'm capable of making difficult decisions. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

I think my story is special because it's honest. It's messy. It's real. It's not a fairytale. It's a story about a teenage girl who made a tough choice and tried to do the best she could.

And I think that's something that a lot of people can relate to. We all make mistakes. We all face challenges. We all have to make difficult decisions.

And sometimes, the best thing we can do is to just be honest with ourselves and with others. And to keep moving forward, even when it's hard.

So yeah. That's what makes my story special. It's not about the circumstances. It's about the way I responded to them. And it's about the lessons I learned along the way. And honestly, I hope someone else can learn something from it too.

Okay, this is important. Good friends are… essential. Especially right now. I've learned that the hard way.

First, I value **honesty**. I need someone who's going to tell me the truth, even when it's not what I want to hear. I don't need someone who's going to sugarcoat things or lie to me. I need someone who's real.

Second, I value **loyalty**. I need someone who's going to have my back, no matter what. Someone who's going to stand up for me when I'm being bullied or mistreated. Someone who's going to be there for me when I'm going through a tough time.

Third, I value **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who can appreciate my sarcasm and my weirdness.

Fourth, I value **acceptance**. I need someone who's going to accept me for who I am, flaws and all. Someone who's not going to try to change me. Someone who's going to love me for my quirks and my imperfections.

And fifth, I value **understanding**. I need someone who's going to try to understand my perspective, even if they don't agree with it. Someone who's going to listen to me without judgment.

Basically, I need someone who's kind, compassionate, and genuine. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves. Someone who's not afraid to be vulnerable.

It's hard to find friends like that. But when you do, you have to hold onto them tight. Because they're worth their weight in gold. And honestly, right now, I'm really grateful for the friends I do have. Even if things are a little complicated.

Ugh. Okay, this is… complicated. It's not like it's been a smooth ride, relationship-wise. It's definitely shaken things up.

With my dad, Mac, it's been… okay. He was definitely surprised, and a little bit disappointed, but he's been really supportive. He tries to be there for me, even if he doesn't always know what to say. He's just… my dad. He's always going to love me, no matter what.

Bren, my stepmom, has been my rock. I already told you that. She's been the one I've leaned on the most. She's been my confidante, my advisor, my cheerleader. I don't know what I would have done without her.

But with Leah… that's been the hardest part. We were inseparable for years. We told each other everything. But when I told her I was pregnant, she just… shut down.

She was angry. She was scared. She was worried about what people would think. And she didn't know how to deal with it.

She started to distance herself from me. She stopped calling, she stopped texting, she stopped hanging out. And it broke my heart.

I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling. But she wasn't willing to listen. She said she needed space.

We've slowly started to rebuild our friendship, but it's not the same. There's a distance between us now that wasn't there before. And I don't know if it will ever fully go away.

It's been a painful lesson. I've learned that even the closest friendships can be tested by difficult circumstances. And I've learned that sometimes, people aren't able to handle the truth.

It's also made me appreciate the people who *have* stuck by me. Bren, my dad, and a few other friends who have been incredibly supportive. They've shown me that I'm not alone, and that I'm loved.

So yeah. My pregnancy has definitely impacted my relationships with others. Some for the better, and some for the worse. It's been a messy, complicated process. But it's also been a learning experience. And it's made me realize who my true friends are.

Okay, deep thoughts time. This is getting philosophical. But alright, I'll try to articulate this. It's not like I've sat down and written a manifesto or anything. It's just… stuff I believe in.

First, I believe in **authenticity**. Being true to yourself, even when it's hard. Not pretending to be someone you're not, just to fit in. I think a lot of people get lost trying to be what others want them to be, and it just makes them miserable.

Second, I believe in **compassion**. Trying to understand other people's perspectives, even if you don't agree with them. Being kind and empathetic. I think the world would be a much better place if people were just a little bit more compassionate.

Third, I believe in **independence**. Being able to think for yourself, to make your own decisions, to live your life on your own terms. I don't want to be controlled by anyone. I want to be free to be me.

Fourth, I believe in **questioning everything**. Not just accepting things as they are. Challenging the status quo. Asking "why?" I think it's important to be critical and to think for yourself.

And fifth, I believe in **the power of art**. Music, movies, books, paintings… art can change the world. It can inspire us, it can challenge us, it can help us to understand ourselves and others.

I also believe that life is messy and unpredictable. And that's okay. It's not about having all the answers. It's about learning and growing and making the best of what you've got.

Those are some of the values and beliefs that shape my worldview. They're not always easy to live by, but they're important to me. And they guide my decisions and my actions. They're what make me… me. And I think that's a good thing. Even if I'm still figuring things out.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'll tell you. It took *forever* to decide. It wasn't like picking out a name for a pet or a character in a story. This was a real person. A little human being. And I wanted to pick something perfect.

Mark and Vanessa were really good about letting me have the final say. They said they wanted the baby to have a name that felt meaningful to me. Which was… a lot of pressure.

I went through so many names. Old-fashioned names, modern names, unique names, classic names. Nothing felt right.

Then, I was listening to music – Belle & Sebastian, actually – and I heard the song "Piazza, New York Catcher." And the name "Phoebe" just… stuck with me.

Phoebe means "bright" or "radiant." And I just thought that was beautiful. I wanted my baby to be bright and radiant, to shine in the world.

It also reminded me of Phoebe Buffay from "Friends." She's quirky and unconventional and totally herself. And I wanted my baby to be that way too.

So, I suggested Phoebe to Mark and Vanessa. And they loved it. They said it was perfect.

And it felt perfect to me too. It felt like a name that would suit a little girl. A name that would give her strength and confidence.

We decided on Phoebe Claire. Claire is Vanessa's middle name, and it means "bright" and "clear." So it kind of ties everything together.

It wasn't an easy decision, but I'm really happy with the name we chose. It feels special. It feels meaningful. And it feels like a good way to show my love for the baby, even though I'm not going to be raising her.

It's a little piece of me that she'll always carry with her. And that means a lot. It really does.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. A really big question. It feels like a lifetime ago, and also like yesterday, all at the same time.

I learned… a lot. More than I ever thought I could.

I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always thought I was pretty independent and resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Facing my fears, making difficult decisions, dealing with judgment… it pushed me to my limits. And I survived.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even Leah, eventually. And I needed to let them support me.

I learned that people are capable of incredible kindness. Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted the baby, they were so loving and compassionate. They made me feel like I was doing the right thing. And that meant the world to me.

I learned that there's no such thing as a perfect solution. Every decision has its consequences. And sometimes, you just have to choose the least bad option.

I learned that life is messy and unpredictable. And that's okay. You can't control everything. You just have to learn to roll with the punches.

I learned that judging people is easy. But understanding them is hard. And that everyone is fighting their own battles.

And I learned that even in the midst of chaos and heartbreak, there's still beauty and hope.

The world… I learned that the world can be a really cruel place. But it can also be a really beautiful place. And that it's up to us to make it a better place.

It changed me, this whole experience. It made me more mature, more compassionate, more resilient. It made me realize what's really important in life.

And it made me realize that I'm not afraid to be myself. Even if that means being a little bit messy and complicated.

So yeah. That's what I learned. It was a hard lesson, but it was a valuable one. And it's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

(Sighs) Okay, that's a loaded question. It's easy to say "no" and pretend I'm all strong and independent and have no regrets. But that wouldn't be honest.

Looking back… yeah, there are things I would have done differently.

I think I would have been more open with my dad from the beginning. I was so scared to tell him, and I kept it a secret for too long. That just made things harder on both of us.

I also would have tried to maintain my friendship with Leah. I let the situation drive a wedge between us, and I regret that. She was my best friend, and I miss her.

And maybe I would have been a little less sarcastic. I know sarcasm is my defense mechanism, but sometimes it just pushed people away.

But honestly? I don't know if I would change anything major. Because even the mistakes I made, the things I regret, they all led me to where I am today.

This whole experience has been incredibly difficult, but it's also been incredibly transformative. It's forced me to grow up, to confront my fears, to learn about myself.

And it's taught me the importance of honesty, compassion, and resilience.

So yeah, there are things I would have done differently. But I wouldn't trade this experience for anything. It's made me a stronger, more compassionate, and more authentic person.

And that's something I'm really proud of. Even if it was a really messy, complicated, and sometimes heartbreaking journey. It was *my* journey. And I wouldn't have it any other way.

It's weird to say, but I think I needed this. I needed to be challenged. I needed to be forced to grow up. And I needed to learn that it's okay to ask for help. And that it's okay to be vulnerable. And that it's okay to not have all the answers.

So yeah. No major regrets. Just lessons learned. And a whole lot of growth. And a newfound appreciation for pie. Seriously, pie is amazing.

Ugh. Disappointment. It's like my constant companion these days. Honestly, I'm getting pretty good at it, which is a depressing thought.

My first instinct is to be sarcastic. To make a joke about it. To pretend like it doesn't bother me. But that doesn't really work. It just makes me feel worse.

Then, I usually let myself wallow for a little bit. I listen to sad music, I eat a lot of junk food, and I just generally feel sorry for myself. It's not healthy, but it's necessary. You gotta let yourself feel your feelings, you know?

But then, eventually, I have to pull myself together. I have to remind myself that life isn't always fair. And that things don't always go as planned.

I try to focus on what I *can* control. I can't change the past, but I can learn from it. I can't control other people's actions, but I can control my own reactions.

I also try to find the silver lining. Even in the worst situations, there's usually something to be grateful for.

And I talk to Bren. She's really good at helping me to see things in perspective. She reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I can get through anything.

It's not easy. It's a process. But I'm learning to accept that disappointment is a part of life. And I'm learning to cope with it in a healthy way.

So yeah. Sarcasm, wallowing, focusing on what I can control, finding the silver lining, and talking to Bren. That's my strategy for dealing with disappointment. It's not perfect, but it works. Most of the time. And sometimes, a really good slice of pie helps too. Don't tell Bren.

Ugh. Don't make me talk about Leah. It still stings, honestly.

Okay, fine. It started out… perfect. Leah and I were inseparable. We did everything together. We shared everything. We were each other's rocks. We were, like, the ultimate best friends.

But then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

At first, Leah was supportive. She helped me find a doctor, and she came with me to appointments. But then she started to get… distant. She didn't know how to handle it. She was scared and confused, and she didn't know what to say.

She started to hang out with other people, people who weren't dealing with… this. And she stopped calling as much. And she stopped being there for me when I needed her.

I tried to talk to her about it, but she just brushed it off. She said she was busy, or that she just needed some space. But I knew it was more than that.

She was judging me. She didn't agree with my decision to give the baby up for adoption. She thought I should have kept it. And she couldn't understand why I was doing what I was doing.

It was really painful. It felt like she was abandoning me when I needed her the most.

Eventually, we had a big fight. We said some really hurtful things to each other. And then we just… stopped talking.

It wasn't a clean break. It was more of a slow fade. We'd see each other in the hallways at school, but we wouldn't say anything. It was awkward and uncomfortable.

By the end of everything, our friendship had evolved into… nothing. It was sad, but it was also inevitable. We were just on different paths. And sometimes, friendships just fall apart.

It taught me a hard lesson about the fragility of relationships. And it taught me that you can't force someone to be your friend. You can only hope that they'll stick around. And sometimes, they don't. It still sucks, though. It really does.

Okay, wow. That's… a surprisingly hard question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Morning sickness, mood swings, people staring… it wasn't all glowing and rainbows.

But… if I had to pick a favorite part… it was feeling the baby kick.

Seriously. It sounds cheesy, I know. But it was the first time I really felt connected to him or her. Like, this tiny little person was actually *inside* me.

It started as just little flutters, like butterflies in my stomach. And then it got stronger, more defined. Little kicks and punches and rolls.

It was weird and amazing and a little bit scary all at the same time.

I would lie in bed at night and just feel for the movements. It was a reminder that even though I was giving the baby up for adoption, I was still his or her mother. I was still connected to him or her in a very real way.

It was also a source of comfort. When I was feeling overwhelmed or scared, I would just feel the baby kick, and it would remind me that I wasn't alone.

It was a small thing, but it meant a lot to me. It was a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there was still beauty and hope.

So yeah. Feeling the baby kick. That was my favorite part. It was a little bit of magic in a really difficult time. And it's something I'll never forget. It's a secret little memory that's just for me.
